Hansard-Body.A: Honourable members, I refer to my statement on 26 May 2011 regarding a document tabled by the honourable member for Burnett on 10 May 2011. In my statement I advised the House that, included within a bundle of various documents tabled by the honourable member, one document had redactions which were ineffective in removing names that could identify a child, which is breach of standing order 35. The House gave leave to approve the Clerk to alter the document to effect proper redactions. The issue relating to redactions is now before the Integrity, Ethics and Parliamentary Privileges Committee. However, an additional matter has now come to light. The tabled document refers to criminal charges instituted almost a year ago and states--

XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: ... criminal charges are now scheduled to be heard in a Bundaberg court on 3 September 2010.
XML.Hansard-Body: However, the Clerk’s delegate has made inquiries with the Bundaberg Police Child Protection Unit and it has been confirmed that the matter referred to in the tabled paper is currently before the courts. I am advised that the matter has been through the committal process in the Magistrates Court and is currently before the District Court. Accordingly, the document is also in breach of the sub judice rule as set out in standing order 233. I have therefore instructed the Clerk to remove the offending document from the bundle of documents. I have also referred this aspect to the committee.

Hansard-Body.A: (Burnett--Ind) (9.33 am): Mr Speaker, I rise on a matter suddenly arising. Mr Speaker, by way of explanation to your statement, the circumstances in which I tabled that bundled document were special and unique circumstances. They involved corruption at the highest levels of Child Safety, through the minister’s office and police--

XML.Hansard-Body: Mr SPEAKER: Order!
Mr REEVES: I rise to a point of order.

Mr SPEAKER: Order! Let me deal with the honourable member first and then I will deal with your point of order. The honourable member will have a chance in the committee. The matter has been referred to the committee. It is not a question of debate now, so I would ask the honourable member, if he feels aggrieved by what I have said, to make sure that he puts those statements to the committee. I call the minister on a point of order.

Mr SPEAKER: Thank you.

Hansard-Body.A: (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for Reconstruction) (9.34 am): I move--

XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: 1. That this House desires to place on record its appreciation of the services rendered to this state by the late Detective Senior Constable Damian Leeding.

2. That Mr Speaker be requested to convey to the family of the deceased gentleman the above resolution, together with an expression of the sympathy and sorrow of the members of this parliament of Queensland, in the loss they have sustained.
XML.Hansard-Body: Honourable members will of course now be aware of the tragic event that occurred on Sunday, 29 May at the Pacific Pines Tavern on the Gold Coast. Armed offenders entered the Pacific Pines Tavern with the intention of committing a robbery and took seven hostages. One of those hostages managed to make a 000 call seeking police assistance and Detective Senior Constable Damian Leeding and his partner, Detective Senior Constable Nicole Jackson, were first on the scene. While trying to apprehend the offenders, Senior Constable Leeding suffered a gunshot wound to the head. He was taken to the Gold Coast Hospital in a critical condition where he was on life support for a further three days. On Wednesday, 1 June, Senior Constable Leeding’s family made the heartbreaking decision to suspend his life support. Damian Leeding is survived by his wife, Sonya, who also serves the people of Queensland as a police officer, their two-year-old son, Hudson, and their three-month-old daughter, Grace.

Senior Constable Leeding was a very well respected officer of the Queensland Police Service with a very bright future in that service. He was regarded by all who worked with him as someone who loved his work, loved his family and was a much loved mate to all. His loss is a great tragedy and a reminder of the risks that our front-line police officers face on a daily basis in their job of protecting all of us. Damian Leeding was laid to rest by his family at a private location last Tuesday following a full police funeral at the Gold Coast Convention Centre which I attended along with a number of representatives of all levels of government and all sides of politics.

The death of this young officer genuinely touched the hearts of all Queenslanders. Thousands of Queenslanders in regions right across the state bought and wore the police ribbon in support of Damian’s family and Damian’s friends. More than 5,000 people paid their respects at the very moving public service, including over 4,000 police officers representing every Australian state, New Zealand, Canada and the United States of America. The public response was not only very heart-warming for Damian’s family but also heart-warming evidence to the entire police family that they and their work are much valued by Queenslanders. Following the service, police officers formed a guard of honour along the Gold Coast Highway for Senior Constable Leeding’s final journey.

During a very emotional funeral service, police colleagues undertook to look after his family and a fund has been established to support them. The fund has so far raised more than $300,000, which I think speaks volumes about the generosity of Queenslanders. The Queensland Police Service announced that it will posthumously bestow its highest award--the Valour Medal--on Damian Leeding for his gallantry. On behalf of all Queenslanders and all members of this House, I extend our heartfelt condolences to Damian Leeding’s wife, his children, his extended family and his friends and colleagues in the Queensland Police Service.

Hansard-Body.A: (Nudgee--ALP) (Minister for Police, Corrective Services and Emergency Services) (9.38 am): I rise to join with the Premier and indeed all members of this House to pay tribute to Detective Senior Constable Damian Leeding. I also place on the record my condolences to his wife, Sonya, his children, Grace and Hudson, and his extended family, friends and colleagues. Nothing can prepare a family for the death of a loved one at work. Nothing can prepare one’s colleagues or indeed the broader community for such tragedies. Any death is a tragedy, but the death of a police officer while he is responding to a crime and attempting to help those in danger and in need is particularly devastating. It is also a terrible reminder to us all that our police officers put their own lives at risk every day to protect all Queenslanders. While we pray that such deaths will not occur, our police officers face those risks with professionalism and courage and I know that all Queenslanders are saddened that we have lost one of our finest and bravest front-line police officers in this way.

XML.Hansard-Body: Whilst a recruit at the Police Academy in 2002, Damian Leeding wrote that he wanted to become a police officer because he believed that he could make a difference within the community, and he did. He worked within the Gold Coast police district and at Coomera initially as a general duties officer. However, his skill, professionalism and enthusiasm soon saw him attain the rank of plain-clothes senior constable. His commitment was recognised during his funeral service, with the Police Commissioner posthumously awarding Damian the Medal of Valour--the Queensland Police Service’s highest award--and also announcing his appointment as detective.

Detective Senior Constable Leeding was an enthusiastic and highly regarded police officer. He had a passion for putting the bad guys before the courts. He was much loved by his family and his work colleagues. The QPS and Queensland have lost an outstanding officer, colleague and friend to many. I know that Damian’s death is being felt hard by those officers who worked with him, as well as the entire police family across Queensland.

The outpouring of emotion from the public in the wake of Damian’s tragic death reinforces the community’s strong support for its police service. Thousands attended his funeral service on the Gold Coast, and I know that this was greatly appreciated by his family and the Police Service generally. Detective Senior Constable Damian Leeding’s life was tragically cut short in the pursuit of safety and security in our community. We will never forget his sacrifice. His name will live on in honour within the Queensland Police Service.

Hansard-Body.A: (Callide--LNP) (Leader of the Opposition) (9.41 am): I rise to speak in support of the condolence motion that has been moved by the Premier and to extend the deepest sympathies of all on this side of the House to the family of Damian Leeding--his wife, Sonya, his children, and his immediate family. It was an extraordinary funeral service for Senior Constable Damian Leeding at the Gold Coast. It was an expression by the community of outrage at the crime that had been committed and an expression of support for the family and for the Police Service generally. It was an extraordinary expression of support, because it needed to be.

XML.Hansard-Body: Senior Constable Damian Leeding lost his life acting on our behalf. Like all Queensland police officers, he responded to a crime that was being committed. He responded on behalf of all of us, and when he was attacked all of us were attacked. When he lost his life, all of us felt the loss. It was an extraordinary display of community support, because all of us appreciate the work that the Queensland police do and appreciate the extent of the tragedy that occurred when this particular policeman lost his life.

I support the motion that has been moved by the Premier and I extend our condolences to Senior Constable Damian Leeding’s family and express our support for the Queensland Police Service in the great job that they do.

Hansard-Body.A: (Beaudesert--TQP) (9.42 am): On behalf of the crossbenchers, I, too, speak in support of the condolence motion moved by the Premier and I join the Leader of the Opposition in expressing my condolences to Damian Leeding’s family. I represented the crossbenchers at Damian’s funeral. Like Damian, I have a daughter called Grace and what has happened really hit home. That evening, Christy and I had a quiet time together and realised the impact Damian’s death has had, not only on his family but also on his friends and the Police Service.

XML.Hansard-Body: As Father Columba Macbeth-Green, who conducted Damian’s funeral service, said, there is no greater sacrifice than to lay down your life for others. I think his words resonated throughout Queensland. Damian was a larrikin and an absolute champion, which is the stuff that Queenslanders are made of. He was a true hero. On behalf of the crossbenchers, I join in support of the Premier’s motion.
Question put--That the motion be agreed to.
Motion agreed to.

Hon. AM BLIGH (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for Reconstruction)
(9.47 am): Each year during the first week of June Queenslanders throughout our state celebrate all that is great about living, working and raising a family in Queensland. Queensland Week is seven days of celebrations focused on what makes us and our state so special. It is about our individuality. It is a celebration of what makes Queensland tick. It is a celebration of the unique Queensland spirit.

Never before has Queensland Week been so important as this year, coming just five months after we faced some of the worst and most challenging and heartbreaking episodes in our history. Over the past week our government has ensured that this year’s event will reserve a special place in history. Queensland Week this year was a celebration of the spirit that has come to characterise the heart of communities the length and breadth of the state as they faced almost unthinkable adversity. As floodwaters engulfed homes, businesses and entire towns, as raging torrents tragically stole family members, friends and neighbours, as communities were brought to their knees by floods and as cyclonic winds the like of which have not been seen in a generation ploughed into our coast, we saw the very best of each other. Strangers came out to help. Neighbours ensured that each others’ homes were cleaned up and repaired. In many cases people took leave from their jobs to get in and do their bit. All around Queensland ordinary people did extraordinary things.

Our police and emergency service crews and our priceless SES volunteers went above and beyond the call of duty, often for weeks at a time. We pulled together as a people and as a state to ensure that, while Queensland took a massive blow, we were able to get back on our feet. Our recovery will be a long journey, but we have already come a very long way. We have returned as near to normal as possible in a remarkably short time. It is largely due to those ordinary, everyday Queenslanders who put in such an extraordinary effort--those people who set an example for the rest of the country, not for reward but out of a sense of pride, community spirit and camaraderie.

Our government felt it was important that those Queenslanders were honoured and remembered during Queensland Week. That is why earlier this year we called for nominations for Queensland disaster heroes medals. An astonishing 3,500 people were nominated and received this special commemorative medal. These are the people who were nominated not by politicians or government officials but by their fellow Queenslanders as a mark of their gratitude.

Over the past week 10 ceremonies have been held to award these medals and honour our local heroes in Gatton, Tully, Townsville, Rockhampton, Bundaberg, Dalby, Emerald, Toowoomba, Ipswich and Brisbane. These events were truly moving because we had a chance to hear some of the heroic tales and local stories. These events were also an opportunity for people who came together during the floods and cyclones to be reunited--people like Doug Hislop and Peter Fenton, the drivers of Mavis the mighty tugboat which manoeuvred the broken away RiverWalk down the Brisbane River and out of harm’s way; people like Danielle Crismani, who set up Baked Relief to feed the hundreds of affected Queenslanders and the thousands of volunteers helping them; people like Dylan McRae, a 12-year-old who got his pregnant mother and two little sisters to safety as floods engulfed his family farm near Rosewood while his dad was away; people like Gwen Braga, the president of the state Meals on Wheels organisation known to many in this House--Gwen rolled up her sleeves and got on with the job despite losing everything in her own home; people like Mark Kempton, who winched 43 people, with his team, into his chopper and to safety from the Lockyer in appallingly dangerous conditions; people like the thousands who came out with buckets, shovels and brooms to join the Mud Army.

These are the inspirational stories of ordinary Queenslanders thrust into shocking circumstances. These are the stories of how they refused to be beaten, dusted themselves off and got on with the job. Their names will now be recorded in our history books thanks to their nominations as disaster heroes by their fellow Queenslanders. I place on record today our gratitude to our local disaster heroes and also to those who noticed and recognised them for what they were and took the trouble to nominate them for special recognition.

As we recognise the heroes of our own disasters, we are mindful that our friends in Christchurch are once again in the grip of a frightening experience, with news overnight of severe aftershocks injuring more people and causing more damage to properties in the region. They are in our thoughts today.

Hansard-Body.A: (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for Reconstruction) (9.52 am): Education creates opportunities for our children and opportunities for our state. A solid education lays a solid foundation for future generations and for future wealth and prosperity. Our government has always been driven by a passion for education and improving the opportunities for young Queenslanders. That is why last week I was pleased to announce the next exciting chapter in Queensland’s education reform journey that commenced almost a decade ago. That journey has seen the introduction of a full year of prep for every Queensland child, providing Queensland students with an additional year of schooling, and in 2008 an increase in the school starting age that brought us into line with other states. The education journey has also seen the introduction of the learning or earning reforms, supporting the future of our 16- to 18-year-olds by keeping them in school and keeping them gainfully employed. We are also rolling out our investment in the early years, providing a kindergarten program for every Queensland child by 2014.

XML.Hansard-Body: It is an exciting time in Queensland’s education system, and our commitment to our children continues with our next big reform. From 2015 when the first full year of prep students reach year 7, they will become the first group of Queensland children to start high school in year 7. By 2015 more than half of these children in year 7 will turn 13 and all of them will be in their eighth year in primary school. They will be ready for the challenges and the new depth of learning that high school can offer. In the majority of states and territories, year 7 students already have access to the specialist facilities and specialist teachers that high school offers.

In addition, Australia is about to embark on the biggest national educational reform since Federation. With the introduction of the new Australian curriculum in maths, science and English in 2012, year 7 children in the majority of Australian jurisdictions will get the essential support they need for these subjects in a high school setting. Our government is committed to ensuring that our year 7 students, when they are of the same age, will have the same learning opportunities and access to specialist teachers and facilities such as dedicated science laboratories as their counterparts in other states.

Our government is determined that Queensland children will lead from the front, not be left behind, as the nation rolls out these new learning opportunities. We recognise that this is a very big change. We know that it means we need to provide schools, parents and families with the support they need to make the transition carefully and appropriately. That is why over the next four years there will be a big investment in new classrooms, in professional development for our teachers, in the delivery of scholarships for those primary school teachers who want to take the opportunity to upgrade their qualifications to teach in a high school setting, and in our non-state school system to ensure they are ready for the change as well. Our government has always been driven by a belief in the transforming power of education and we are very pleased to take the next step in what we believe is an important and exciting journey.

Hon. PT LUCAS (Lytton--ALP) (Deputy Premier and Attorney-General, Minister for Local Government and Special Minister of State)
(9.56 am): Earlier this month I attended my first meeting of the Ministerial Council on Consumer Affairs. At the meeting ministers received the first-ever report on implementation of the Australian Consumer Law, a priority element of the Council of Australian Governments’ commitment to a seamless national economy. The new Australian Consumer Law took effect on 1 January this year in all jurisdictions. As the meeting communique noted, the Australian Consumer Law has been delivered on time and in full, which is a major achievement. The Australian Consumer Law is important because it simplifies, strengthens and broadens consumer protection for all Queenslanders.

Ministers also agreed that the Commonwealth and Queensland would lead work to provide enhanced consumer protections to the many millions of Australians who purchase gift cards each year. Too many consumers are being ripped off. Too many consumers are falling foul of expiry dates and other terms and conditions which prevent them from realising the full value of their gift cards. It is wrong that some businesses benefit from the massive amounts of money paid by consumers for gift cards when those consumers have received absolutely nothing in return. We are going to fix this problem, not just for Queenslanders but also for all Australians. At the meeting it was also agreed that a national strategy was needed to detect, pursue and disrupt the actions of those conmen who continue to engage in unlawful door-to-door selling.

I also attended the COAG Select Council on Gambling Reform meeting in Canberra on 27 May. The federal government’s proposed reforms include the requirement for all gaming venues to implement a nationally consistent precommitment system with mandatory player enrolment. Ministers agreed that precommitment is a useful tool to help gamblers define their expenditure and stick to limits but did not agree on whether precommitment should be mandatory or voluntary to the player. Queensland supports a voluntary system. However, ministers did agree that all new gaming machines will be required to have precommitment functionality from a date to be agreed and asked senior officials to undertake further work on precommitment functionality and implementation time frames. The Queensland government wholeheartedly supports the select council’s agreement that small venues require special consideration with regard to the implementation of any precommitment system.

Another example of the progressive work done at select council is a discussion of the promotion of live-betting odds during sporting events. This is a potentially harmful practice as it has the potential to normalise young people to gambling. The select council agreed to take action to reduce and control this promotion. The Queensland government looks forward to continuing to work alongside state and territory governments and the Australian government in relation to these and other reforms.

Hon. AP FRASER (Mount Coot-tha--ALP) (Treasurer and Minister for State Development and Trade)
(9.58 am): Investment is returning to Queensland and in a significant way. It is being led by our resources sector and investment in gas, and it is set to power the rest of the economy. Queensland is fortunate to have these natural resources, but we also need to work to develop our industries of the future. Labor in government has been committed to advancing this agenda.

In the past few weeks I have seen firsthand this dynamic change taking hold in our economy. I recently opened Queensland’s first stem cell processing and storage business in Queensland in Meadowbrook, in the electorate of Waterford, where I was accompanied by the member for Waterford. StemTech is the name of that facility. The StemTech facility, which was assisted into our state by Trade and Investment Queensland, provides the opportunity to store cord blood cells from newborn babies to provide the sort of insurance that money could not previously buy. In the past, cord blood cells were considered a waste product and today they can provide the gift of life into the future.

I have also opened a world-class oncology compounding centre at Geebung, in the electorate of the Minister for Police and Corrective Services, that will supply vital chemotherapy drugs and other specialised intravenous products to Queensland hospitals and clinics. The centre, run by Fresenius Kabi Australia, already employs 20 people and is a $5 million investment in a high-technology facility in our state.

The government has worked closely with both companies to facilitate their move and their investment in Queensland. There was strong competition from other states, but we were determined to help them ensure they could invest here, given the potential lucrative long-term returns to the Queensland economy and the growth in cutting-edge science that they represent to our state.

Recently I also attended a special function at the Wesley Hospital, in my own electorate, at which Mincom, one of this state’s great business triumphs and a world leader in mining technology, is donating $1.5 million to the Wesley Research Institute’s tissue bank. This is an enormously generous contribution to important medical research, and Mincom needs to be recognised for this great act of corporate citizenry. The tissue bank provides medical researchers with an invaluable resource for investigating the origins and development of cancers and other diseases.

I have also attended a function at which one of our leading universities recognised its best and brightest researchers. The University of Queensland is one of the state’s great treasures. It is a world-class institution with world-class minds doing world-class research. That fact is well reflected in the recent QS World University Rankings for technical subjects, in which UQ listed in the top 40 in the world. UQ also did exceptionally well in the recent Australian Research Council’s Excellence in Research for Australia--ERA--report 2010. UQ’s smart-state disciplines of neuroscience, biotechnology, nanotechnology and most areas of biological science were rated by ERA as above world standard, which is ERA’s maximum rating.

These strengths, 21st century institutions, excellent researchers and best-of-the-best technology, coupled with a strong entrepreneurial spirit and a well-oiled IP process providing certainty to investors, will continue to attract investment and jobs--the jobs of the future and the economic future of our state in the 21st century. As a government, we remain committed to delivering the jobs of the future, just as we said we would.
In conclusion, I send a quick ‘get well’ to Claire Atkinson. Our thoughts and best wishes are with Sharon and Bob. Certainly we miss you at the moment.

Hansard-Body.A: (Greenslopes--ALP) (Minister for Education and Industrial Relations) (10.02 am): Last week I had the pleasure of joining the Premier to announce the next stage of Labor’s reforms for education in this state. The Labor Party has always been the party of reform, and there is no clearer example of our reform vision than in the education system. We want Queensland students to receive the best possible education so that they have every opportunity to succeed in life. The Premier has already outlined in some detail the government’s plan for year 7 to join high school in 2015. The benefits of this move will be substantial for our children, who represent the future of this great state. The government has developed a comprehensive package of programs to support the transition of year 7 into high school.

XML.Hansard-Body: I assure parents that year 7 students attending state schools from 2015 will be well supported through pastoral care programs as they make the move to high school. To help achieve this, amongst other things we will introduce junior secondary into Queensland state high schools--a school within a school. Junior secondary will have its own distinct identity and cater for the specific academic and developmental needs of students in years 8 and 9 from 2013, with year 7 joining in 2015. Year 7 students will be eased into high school life with fewer subjects and teachers than higher grades, but at the same time they will be able to take advantage of the educational opportunities that high schools can offer.

We want students in rural and remote areas to have the same opportunities as their city counterparts, but we recognise that their families face additional challenges due to distance. To help support them, we will increase the living-away-from-home allowance for year 7 students to the secondary school rate, conduct a comprehensive review of the educational needs of geographically isolated students and the services offered to them and, with the Catholic and independent school sectors, establish a cross-sectoral task force to examine the financial implications of the change on boarding schools.

Also, I assure state school teachers that no permanent staff will lose their job or be forced to relocate as a result of this important initiative. Those wishing to make the move to junior secondary will have access to professional development programs. The government will also fund up to 500 scholarships for those primary school teachers looking for the challenge of teaching in a secondary school setting. Principal pay scales are also guaranteed for three years from 2015. This government acknowledges the importance of teachers and principals in educating our children. In implementing this important change, we pledge to continue to work closely with the Queensland Teachers Union and principals to make this transition as smooth as possible. Between now and 2015 there is much to be done to get high schools ready for year 7 students to join them, and we are committed to getting on with the job.

This initiative is backed by significant financial resources to ensure the transition is successful--just as we did when we implemented prep in recent years. Over the next four years the government will allocate $328.2 million in extra capital funding for state schools. This will pay for more than 1,400 new and refurbished classrooms and learning areas in state high schools. Also, the government will provide an extra $293.8 million in recurrent funding over forward estimates to implement the suite of initiatives outlined in the Flying Start white paper. This includes $81.3 million for capital assistance to the non-state-school sector. In total, the government has allocated $622 million over the forward estimates. We believe this is a generous and sufficient allocation.

The government acknowledges that further funding will be required beyond the forward estimates period to fully implement the Flying Start initiatives. This is expected to total a further $268 million up to 2017-18. From 2018-19 onwards, about $70 million a year in additional funding for year 7 in high school will be required. This investment reflects our view that the best investment a government can make is in the education of its young people. Through this latest initiative, the Bligh government is ensuring Queensland students can get a flying start to learning and to life.

Hansard-Body.A: (Whitsunday--ALP) (Minister for Tourism, Manufacturing and Small Business) (10.06 am): It is official: the whales are back! The mighty humpbacks have entered the warm waters of Queensland, signalling an early start to the 2011 whale-watching season. I am pleased to announce that our $440,000 Tourism Queensland campaign is now underway, promoting the Fraser Coast’s enviable position as our whale-watching capital. This lively campaign will include promotions and activities, as well as wonderful school holiday events. We want everyone to know that, as well as being the state where Australia shines, we are the winter home for these majestic creatures.

XML.Hansard-Body: All the way from the Gold Coast to Cairns, and right through the winter months to November, Queensland is home to these spectacular, curious and inspiring ocean mammals. And what better place to see them up close and personal than the Fraser Coast, where whales frolic and play in the calm, warm and safe waters of Hervey Bay? Last year’s season drew to the region around 60,000 visitors from across Queensland, interstate and overseas, injecting some $80 million into the local economy.

As well as promotional activities, this year’s campaign will include Twitter and Flickr feeds, so our whale-watching tour operators will be tweeting whale sightings and whale facts as well as posting the latest whale photos. I am pleased to say that on Thursday, 7 July in the Queen Street Mall there will be a special celebration to showcase this very special season. It will feature prizes and giveaways, performances, workshops for children and even rolling footage on the big screen showing the action taking place in Hervey Bay. I invite all honourable members to join me on this very exciting occasion.

Not only does the whale-watching season benefit local tourism operators on the Fraser Coast; the benefits flow to the entire region and throughout our prized coastal areas. That is why I am pleased to announce that in 2012 we will be rolling out a new, whole-of-state campaign promoting whale watching along the Fraser Coast, as well as many of our other tourism hotspots up and down our incredible coastline. Queensland: there’s no better place on earth. And I am proud to promote it, because it is where Australia shines.

Hon. KJ JONES (Ashgrove--ALP) (Minister for Environment and Resource Management) (10.09 am): Climate change is one of the biggest threats to Queensland’s environment. This has been made absolutely clear in a report by environmental expert Tim Low titled Climate change and Queensland biodiversity . This is one of the first detailed investigations into the impact of climate change on Queensland’s biodiversity. It addresses the anticipated effects of climate change including the severity and frequency of drought, fire and cyclones and what this all means for Queensland’s vulnerable habitats and species.

This scientific report warns that climate change impacts on our biodiversity could include deaths of millions of birds in South-West Queensland, as well as losses of other species in locations across Queensland, especially the Wet Tropics, the gulf, the mulga lands and the Central Queensland coast, all of which are particularly vulnerable to changes in rainfall and temperature.

Queensland is home to a range of rare plants and species, half of which are found nowhere else in the world. They are a crucial part of what makes Queensland such a beautiful place to visit and are vital to our economy. This report not only is a timely reminder that we all share the responsibility of ensuring that our wildlife and environment are protected for future generations to experience and appreciate but also demonstrates why we need to have real action in reducing carbon emissions today.

Our government has a strong track record in arresting the decline of biodiversity through vegetation management laws, reef protection legislation and habitat conservation and expansion, but more can be done. That is why we have been developing a state-wide biodiversity strategy aimed at identifying these key threats to our unique biodiversity. The draft strategy, which will be finalised this year, will deliver a framework to ensure we protect vulnerable species, continue to increase protected areas and ensure the survival of critical ecosystems. Mr Low’s research will help us better understand the potential impacts of climate change and better respond to these threats and challenges.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Gallery of Modern Art, Surrealist Art Exhibition
XML.Hansard-Body: Hon. RG NOLAN (Ipswich--ALP) (Minister for Finance and the Arts) (10.11 am): The latest exhibition at the Gallery of Modern Art is already shaping up to be a huge drawcard for residents, tourists and visitors. After the Premier officially opened Surrealism: The Poetry of Dreams on Friday night, early reports show that, in the first three days alone, more than 5,000 people have visited the exhibition. This is the first major survey of surrealist art in Australia in more than 17 years and is completely exclusive to Brisbane. So this is a big coup for Queensland.

Speaking at the opening of the exhibition on Friday night, the Pompidou Centre’s president, Alain Seban, who had travelled all the way from Paris to be at the opening, said that this was the best and most innovative touring exhibition that the Pompidou Centre had ever done and that, while the Pompidou does not travel its work widely, it chose Brisbane because of our world-class Gallery of Modern Art and because our city is quickly becoming acknowledged as the arts hub of all of South-East Asia.

This extraordinary exhibition is open until 2 October and brings to Australia works from the Musée National d’Art Moderne at Paris’s iconic Centre Pompidou, which holds Europe’s finest surrealist collection. We are lucky to see in Queensland works of this calibre because, as I said, the Centre Pompidou’s surrealist collection rarely leaves France. There are more than 180 works in the exhibition by 55 artists, dating from 1913 to the late 1970s. So in that sense, it is a far more comprehensive historical record of surrealism than is your standard exhibition.

Since GoMA opened almost five years ago, the gallery has generated a $45 million boost to tourism and the state economy, with half of visitors to international ticketed exhibitions living outside Brisbane. I have no doubt that this exhibition will continue that trend. I encourage all members to go if they have the opportunity and to encourage their constituents to do the same.

Visitors to GoMA know it for its large open spaces. However, the gallery has been completely transformed into a labyrinth journey through the minds of the surrealists. As well as surrealist films in GoMA’s Cinematheque, Surrealism for Kids activities in the Children’s Art Centre, the Friday night Up Late program, and a discussion series, there will be a world-first English language publication on the Pompidou’s surrealist collection.

This exhibition is one of a trifecta of world-class exhibitions to be shown at GoMA and the Queensland Art Gallery this year and next. In December we will see Matisse: Drawing Life to mark the fifth anniversary of GoMA, while next year Portrait of Spain: Masterpieces from the Prado will mark 30 years of the Queensland Art Gallery. It is because of exhibitions such as these that our Gallery of Modern Art and the Queensland Art Gallery are now Australia’s most popular museums. When we built GoMA five years ago just 300,000 people a year were visiting the old Queensland Art Gallery. Now 1.8 million people visit the two campuses each year, making this the biggest art gallery in Australia.

Hon. CW PITT (Mulgrave--ALP) (Minister for Disability Services, Mental Health and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Partnerships) (10.14 am): The ABC’s flagship current affairs program, Four Corners , recently highlighted changes that had taken place over time in Queensland’s Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities. The contrast between Aurukun under the Bjelke-Petersen regime and Aurukun today under a Labor government could not be more stark. Our groundbreaking policies have helped shape communities where school attendance is up and levels of violence are down. On the Four Corners special, Aurukun was held up as a beacon of hope and an example of what can be achieved when people and communities embrace reform with courage and conviction.

The Cape York Welfare Reform trial has played no small part in bringing about change for the people in Aurukun, as well as Mossman Gorge, Hope Vale and Coen. The trial began in 2008 in partnership with the federal government, the Cape York institute and the men, women and children of those four communities. While the results are promising, we know that there is more work to be done. To this end, I am holding talks with mayors and community leaders on the future of the trial. I also want to hear from justice groups, service providers and residents in the trial communities.

Many people have had a role to play in the early success of the trial. One organisation’s achievements in particular ring loud and clear, and that is the Family Responsibilities Commission. As I said, it is a shining example of what can be achieved when communities embrace reform with courage and conviction. It links welfare payments to social benchmarks, including school attendance--and its results in getting children to school have been a success as well as a re-establishment of local authority. Between semester 1 of 2008 and semester 1 of last year, school attendance rates in Aurukun increased from 43.7 per cent to 62.1 per cent.

The Cape York Welfare Reform trial is about closing the gap on the health, education and wellbeing of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people with practical policies and sensible solutions right in the heart of local communities. I am hopeful that these reforms will deliver lasting, long-term benefits, and I am keen to listen and learn from local communities as to where to from here.

Hansard-Body.A: (Thuringowa--ALP) (Minister for Main Roads, Fisheries and Marine Infrastructure) (10.16 am): I am pleased to report that one of the worst affected sites on the Cunningham’s Gap has reached a major milestone thanks to our $40 million reconstruction program, which is part of Operation Queenslander. In a huge engineering feat, piling work is now complete at Fig Tree Gully. The work saw drilling of 40 deep holes, some up to 25 metres in depth, along the edge of the road and then filling those holes with concrete to stabilise the area. The gap certainly did not escape the wrath of the natural disasters which struck our state earlier this year. They left behind a path of destruction including significant damage along a seven-kilometre stretch of the Cunningham Highway.

XML.Hansard-Body: This government is getting on with the job of rebuilding Queensland. Indeed, this morning the government announced nearly $1 billion in repair and reconstruction works for Central Queensland roads under our NDRRA program. This is in addition to $300 million we announced at Mackay. This is an extraordinary level of funding and it will bring massive job benefits to these regions. In Central Queensland alone, 3,000 jobs will be created. I thank the members for Rockhampton and Keppel, who have been very vocal in calling for these works to be undertaken. I am sure they will welcome this nearly $1 billion in funding. There could be no more graphic illustration that Operation Queenslander is moving into high gear than these huge road repair projects. We are reconnecting communities and getting industries moving again.

Back to the gap, we are building a better, stronger and more resilient highway. Main Roads is carrying out an unprecedented engineering procedure. When we are finished, the road will be safer than it has ever been. The next step is to ‘cap’ the concrete piles and reinforce them with 1,100 cubic metres of concrete and 250 tonnes of steel to form a new retaining structure which will be anchored to the rock face beneath the road. With 80 workers on site, we are supporting local businesses--from the motels where the workers are staying to nearby service stations, trade suppliers and, of course, the local pie shop. I thank my staff from Main Roads, who have done a great job there. In fact, we monitor that site 24 hours a day to look for slippages. It is part of an important reconstruction effort across the state.

Hon. TS MULHERIN (Mackay--ALP) (Minister for Agriculture, Food and Regional Economies) (10.19 am): QRAA has been instrumental in keeping Queensland’s flood recovery on track. As at 2 June 2011, QRAA has approved more than $89 million in grant and loan assistance to more than 9,500 primary producers, businesses and not-for-profit organisations affected by the recent natural disasters.

In keeping this support on track, a new chair has been appointed to the QRAA board. Former National Australia Bank agribusiness general manager for Australia, Wayne Carlson, took up the appointment on 3 June. As chair, Mr Carlson will report to me on the performance of QRAA’s functions. Mr Carlson’s 35 years of experience in the rural finance sector will help QRAA adapt to changing trends and embrace opportunities for growth. His background with agribusiness will inform his views and decisions in this position, and I believe he will be a valuable addition to the QRAA team.

In addition, three new directors have been appointed to the board. I would also like to welcome John Pollock, Georgie Somerset and Sarah Israel as new board directors. The chair appointment follows the departure of retiring chairperson, Graham Davies, who is well known and well liked within the industry for his dedication to the role and service to government. This dedication was recognised yesterday when he was awarded an AM in the Queen’s birthday honours. I congratulate Graham on that achievement.

I also thank other retiring board members Matthew Hood and Richard Stevens, who are leaving the board. Their hard work, particularly in response to the challenges presented during and following the summer of natural disasters, has been outstanding.

QRAA continues to be responsive to the needs of stakeholders, particularly with adapting the application process. For example, AgForce recently suggested changes to the natural disaster assistance loan application form to achieve efficiencies in the processing of money to impacted producers. This small but important example of responsiveness is the type of change that is needed to keep our flood recovery on track.

Hon. A PALASZCZUK (Inala--ALP) (Minister for Transport and Multicultural Affairs)
(10.21 am): Last Monday this government unveiled the largest public transport timetable overhaul in more than 15 years. We added more than 200,000 weekly seats for customers on some of our busiest trains and buses across the network, meeting our commitment to add more than 305,000 additional weekly seats in the current financial year.

The 6 June package added 150,000 more weekly train seats, more reliability and more frequency to the Caboolture, Ipswich, Rosewood, Richlands and north coast rail lines. Trains now run through Roma Street and Central stations every three minutes during the busiest times. There are also more off-peak, weekend and public holiday services.

Trains operate at least every 15 minutes between Darra and the city and four trains an hour between Northgate and the city. TransLink has also added 50,000 seats per week to services and adjusted times to ensure connections on more than 80 bus routes across South-East Queensland.

There have been high-frequency upgrades on route 120 to Upper Mount Gravatt and on route 196 between New Farm and Fairfield. There are additional services in the corridor between Indooroopilly and the University of Queensland, and I know that the shadow minister for transport will be very pleased with that announcement. There are also more services for Bray Park, Inala and Tennyson.

Queensland Rail and Translink are monitoring all services during the early stages of this timetable rollout. I want to thank all members of the public and members here who have provided input and feedback. We are only one week into such a large public transport change but the feedback from customers has been both positive and constructive. TransLink and Queensland Rail will continue to have even more helping hands staff out on public transport and at major stations this week as the transition continues.

Hon. S ROBERTSON (Stretton--ALP) (Minister for Energy and Water Utilities) (10.23 am): There are some very interesting figures that I feel important to share to show the House today how innovative and effective our water infrastructure is when faced with unprecedented circumstances. We all know that a natural disaster can leave lasting damage. However, it is yet to be shared the true level of damage that has occurred to our catchments and therefore the quality of our raw water in our key water storages.

Mr Speaker, 60,000 tonnes per day of sediment was released from Wivenhoe Dam during the peak of the flood, and 315,000 tonnes is the estimated amount of sediment that flowed out of Wivenhoe Dam following the flood event in January. It is estimated that one million tonnes of sediment flowed from the Brisbane and Lockyer catchments over the Mount Crosby Weir--60 kilometres downstream of Wivenhoe--over the same period.

What this demonstrates is that the extreme nature of the floods resulted in an unprecedented volume of sediment not only flowing through Wivenhoe Dam but flowing into the Brisbane River from both the Lockyer and Bremer rivers. Such was the force of the flows into Wivenhoe Dam that for the first time water quality across the entire lake was adversely impacted. The reality is that the current elevated levels of turbidity within Wivenhoe are likely to remain for at least another year and perhaps longer.

Poor raw water quality presents real tests for water treatment plants like the two at Mount Crosby which process the main supply for Brisbane. Regardless of how long it takes for our catchments to recover, water from our taps will remain safe, clean and of the highest quality. Why? Because of the South-East Queensland water grid, which offers a secure water supply of the highest quality.

The water grid allows us to transfer water to where it is needed most. Dual flow pipelines allow us to move treated drinking water from Noosa to Coolangatta and out to the Lockyer Valley. It allows us to choose our water from both new and existing sources across the region, and it allows us to blend our water sources. We are also able to draw on the Gold Coast desalination plant as a climate resilient source, as we did in the immediate aftermath of the January floods, to supplement our water supply whenever it is required.

The Bligh government not only drought proofed South-East Queensland with the water grid but is still proving its worth. This government has made sure that even during some of the worst natural disasters this state has faced our water quality was not compromised.

Hon. SJ HINCHLIFFE (Stafford--ALP) (Minister for Employment, Skills and Mining) (10.25 am): The Productivity Commission’s recent report into climate change has identified gas fired power as being the most cost-effective method of lowering greenhouse gas emissions. I am pleased to say that Queensland is already playing a key role in fuelling worldwide energy demands for gas, which is a cleaner, lower emission fuel.

The reality is that the established coal seam gas industry and the emerging liquefied natural gas industry are good for Queensland’s economy and good for our environment, as the Productivity Commission’s report shows. This government supports the balanced development of the industries and recognises their potential to bring employment opportunities to Queenslanders.

The three LNG export projects that have state government and federal government approval could bring up to $65 billion in investment in Queensland and some 18,000 jobs. This demand is being driven by increasing international demand, with key export markets identified in Japan and China, who are seeking lower emission transition fuels such as LNG. The truth is that, if big economies like those in Asia turn to Queensland LNG instead of coal for large scale power generation, their greenhouse gas emissions will be significantly reduced.

The Bligh government is also aware of the need to balance the development of the industry with agriculture, the environment and impacts on communities and landholders. That is why we have introduced strict legislation to achieve a more favourable outcome for all players. Our laws ensure landholders are fully aware and fairly compensated for activities undertaken by resource companies on their land. They require companies to enter into legally binding conduct and compensation agreements with affected landholders.

Petroleum and gas companies are also now subject to compulsory new reporting requirements for all exploration and production activities that they plan to carry out. The safety of the industry was recently highlighted in an industry-wide audit of Queensland’s CSG wells which showed that 98 per cent of wells had no leaks. I am confident that this balanced approach to the development of the industry will lead to a prosperous future for Queensland and a ready source of cleaner energy for the world.

Hon. GJ WILSON (Ferny Grove--ALP) (Minister for Health) (10.28 am): The Bligh government is committed to ensuring all Queenslanders can access quality health care. That is why we are developing innovative new strategies to help outpatients see an outpatient specialist sooner.

Last financial year Queensland Health provided more than 2.35 million specialist outpatient clinic appointments to outpatients. I have made it clear that no outpatient needing an urgent consultation should ever be turned away. I have also directed that any category 1 outpatient must be treated at their local clinic, not referred on. The director-general has delivered this message to district CEOs.

At my direction Queensland Health has, for some time, been working on strategies to streamline outpatient clinics so patients can see a specialist sooner. This is being led by the Centre for Healthcare Improvement under the leadership of Acting Director-General Tony O’Connell. These strategies include working more closely with local GPs.

All Queensland Health districts have been informed by the director-general of their responsibility to make contact with GPs in the rare instances when re-referral letters are issued to ensure alternatives are explored. Alternatives might include assessment or treatment by an allied health professional such as a physiotherapist or occupational therapist, for example. It might also include referring outpatients to another nearby clinic with a shorter waiting list than the one closest to them.

A project at the Metro North Health Service District in which referrals were reviewed by an in-house GP substantially improved the time in which outpatients could be seen. The GP was able to reduce the number of follow-up appointments waiting on the list so follow-up outpatients got care sooner and outpatients waiting for new appointments moved higher up the waiting list to be seen sooner. The project evaluation also found that in many cases referral to other clinicians, such as allied health staff, was more appropriate.

Other new strategies recently implemented are already showing results as well. At Logan, for example, a new nurse led screening clinic for endoscopy services has improved access to the service for outpatients, meaning the most urgent outpatients are able to see their specialists sooner, in line with their clinical urgency. After a successful trial at three outpatient sites, orthopaedic physiotherapy screening clinics are now operating at 13 facilities state-wide, including Ipswich, Townsville, the RBWH, the PA, Gold Coast, Mater Adults, Logan, Toowoomba, the Mater Children’s Hospital, Nambour, Redcliffe, Cairns and Mackay. In just the first eight months at Mackay, 302 new cases were reviewed by the musculoskeletal physiotherapist working in the screening clinic within orthopaedic outpatients. That was a 61 per cent increase in the number of new outpatients who were seen in that period.

I made it clear when I first became health minister that tackling outpatient waiting lists was one of my key priorities. This work already underway is proof that we take this issue extremely seriously.

Hansard-Body.A: (Mansfield--ALP) (Minister for Child Safety and Minister for Sport) (10.31 am): The Bligh government understands that sport and recreation clubs are the lifeblood of our communities. That is why I am delighted to announce the opening of the Sport and Recreation Infrastructure Program for 2011. We have $20 million worth of sports grants up for grabs. From Bowen to Brisbane, from Cairns to Coolangatta, sport and recreation clubs are pumped about this. As members will be aware, we put this program on hold following the summer of natural disasters. All efforts were redirected into our Sports Flood Fight Back Plan and the recovery of flood and cyclone affected clubs. Our focus has been on rebuilding Queensland, but now we are moving forward and investing in a program that will benefit Queenslanders across the state.

XML.Hansard-Body: This program will help clubs build new or upgraded facilities to encourage Queenslanders to lead more active lives. To top it off, the program will also create much needed jobs across the state. The funding can be used for a range of options, from the construction of facilities and additional playing fields to new lighting, shade structures and playing surfaces. Clubs can also use the grants to repair flood affected facilities. Up to $300,000 is available for minor projects, which means that clubs can apply for up to 75 per cent of projects which are worth $400,000. Also, up to $750,000 is available for medium-sized projects, meaning clubs can apply for 60 per cent of a project worth $1.25 million. The Bligh government will allocate the full $20 million in the one round, so I urge clubs to get their applications in by 25 July so they do not miss out.

This infrastructure program will complement our other funding initiatives, including the Positive or it’s Pointless equipment grants and the Local Sport and Recreation Jobs Plan program, both of which are now open. This is on top of the $15 million which was provided to flood and cyclone affected clubs to help them get back on their feet.

To ensure clubs know what assistance is available, our sport and recreation funding information sessions will be hitting the road. Over the next few weeks, sessions will be held around the state, kicking off in Roma tomorrow. It is a great opportunity for clubs to find out the finer details of how the program works, how they can apply and what they can apply for. Essentially, it is a one-stop shop for sports funding. By investing in sport and recreation clubs, we are investing in the future of healthy living. We want to boost participation levels in sport and recreation by providing first-class facilities for all Queenslanders.

Hansard-Body.A: (Yeerongpilly--ALP) (Minister for Government Services, Building Industry and Information and Communication Technology) (10.34 am): The results of a recent national survey of government services show that Queensland’s continued performance as the Smart State is gaining national recognition. Smart Service Queensland, the ‘front door’ to the Queensland government, has been recognised as one of the best government service providers in the country. During 2010, research based consulting group Customer Service Benchmarking Australia carried out an assessment of Smart Service Queensland’s customer service standards. The performance of Smart Service Queensland was compared to four similar customer service providers--Canberra Connect, Service South Australia, Service Tasmania and the Brisbane City Council--and I am pleased to say that Smart Service Queensland passed the test with flying colours.

XML.Hansard-Body: Smart Service Queensland recorded a customer satisfaction score of 170 out of a possible 200 in the face-to-face service category. The performance of Smart Service Queensland’s Government Service Centre saw a customer satisfaction score well above the overall average of 158; in fact, we bettered the average by 12 points. Visitors to the Government Service Centre had an average wait time of 116 seconds to speak with an agent. This was the second-fastest wait time--a full 84 seconds faster than the overall average of 200 seconds. Smart Service Queensland’s website--www.qld.gov.au--recorded an overall score of 86, seven points ahead of the overall average of 79. The website was regarded as friendly and informative, with an easy-to-find search box, appropriate text size and clear images.

This survey relied on mystery shoppers to evaluate the quality of the services being delivered. These mystery shoppers rated Smart Service’s phone services better than its interstate counterparts and equal best with the Brisbane City Council at the local government level. Smart Service Queensland managed almost 14 million customer contacts in 2010-11. This is an enormous volume of transactions and it is a testament to the skill, dedication and hard work of all its staff. I thank them all for their efforts to entrench Queensland’s reputation as the Smart State.

Hansard-Body.A: (Algester--ALP) (Minister for Community Services and Housing and Minister for Women) (10.36 am): Like many, an elderly Yeronga resident has had a tough time since his rented property was flooded. To add to his troubles, he fell ill and, not able to pay his rent, he faced eviction. The Bligh government is committed for the long-term flood recovery effort. We have boosted funds to services that are helping people get back on their feet. After making contact with the Acacia Ridge Tenant Advice and Advocacy Service, he was referred to Micah Projects’ Flood Recovery Housing and Support Service and is being assisted into secure affordable housing.

XML.Hansard-Body: This is an example of the Bligh government’s whatever-it-takes approach to housing and supporting people through the flood and cyclone recovery period. Micah Projects is now being given a funding boost to provide practical assistance across Brisbane for 12 months as part of the ongoing follow-up in the flood recovery process. We are in this for the long haul; we are not cutting and running. Recovery workers can assist those in need to access alternative housing; identify resources, services and entitlements; link with financial counselling, mental health services and legal services; and provide support for people dealing with personal or family matters.

I express my gratitude to Micah Projects along with other NGOs and community organisations, like the Acacia Ridge Community Centre, the Centenary Recovery Centre and the Yeronga Recovery Centre, and I thank the member for Yeerongpilly here. I joined him on Friday in his electorate to provide support to the Yeronga Recovery Centre. We passed on 35 handmade bears that had been donated from a very kind woman in South Australia, and we provided $50,000. The member for Yeerongpilly had been calling for that support, so I thank him for his advocacy. I also thank West End Community House, the Sherwood Neighbourhood Centre, the New Farm Neighbourhood Centre and many others locally for the great work they have been doing. These groups are committed to improving the lives of Brisbane residents.

With around 25,000 Brisbane homes affected by January’s floods, words cannot express the devastation people felt. The Department of Communities conducted over 30,000 face-to-face assessments through outreach and recovery centres in the first six weeks alone. We have paid out more than $8.8 million in financial assistance grants to more than 16,000 people just in the Brisbane region alone. The work continues and we are committed to whatever it takes to make that happen.

Hansard-Body.A: (Nudgee--ALP) (Minister for Police, Corrective Services and Emergency Services) (10.39 am): Earlier this year tens of thousands of everyday Queenslanders worked alongside SES volunteers to help clean up following the floods and cyclones that impacted our state during our summer of sorrow. The work they undertook provided great satisfaction and a sense of achievement in helping their community when it was needed most. This is exactly what SES volunteers do all year round. That is why the state government has launched a new campaign to encourage those who pitched in following the floods and cyclones to join the SES. A 30-second television advertisement is currently screening focusing on the fantastic community response by thousands of volunteers who helped strangers and neighbours recover from the disasters. The advertisement encourages these community-minded people to consider joining the SES.

XML.Hansard-Body: There are currently around 6,800 volunteers state-wide who don the orange overalls to ensure the community receives the assistance it requires in times of need. One of the great things about the SES is that there are a vast range of practical skills that people can learn which transfer over to their everyday lives. In addition to this, those who already possess certain skills like radio operations or abseiling or chainsaw operations can have the chance to hone and utilise these skills in potentially life-saving environments. I recognise that this type of work and volunteering is not for everyone, but I hope that those people who are looking for another opportunity to contribute to community safety in Queensland take the opportunity to join their local SES group.

While our current volunteers do a fantastic job, an ageing population and change in work patterns mean the need to attract more people to the SES is a priority. Having a strong volunteer base with steady recruitment will ensure the SES remains a world-class service to all Queenslanders, and in that regard I acknowledge the partnership that the state government has in recruitment and supporting the SES with local governments all over Queensland. Anyone interested in finding out more about the SES should call 13QGOV or 137468 or contact their local council or Emergency Management Queensland office and ask about signing up with their local unit.

(10.43 am): My first question without notice is to the Treasurer. I refer to the Treasurer’s claim last year that his plan for the sale of Queensland’s assets was ‘to pay down debt’. Given that the Treasurer has now sold the $17 billion worth of assets but still lost the state’s AAA credit rating and is today planning for a $2 billion deficit and projecting debt to increase to a massive $85 billion, how can any Queenslander not conclude that our state economy is managed by Australia’s worst state Treasurer who today will hand down a budget that nobody will believe?

XML.Hansard-Body: Mr FRASER: I thank the Leader of the Opposition for his question. Let me make this point really clearly, and I will say it slowly: in the budget that I hand down this afternoon, as I said in the public arena yesterday, debt in this state will be $17 billion lower than was forecast--$17 billion lower than was forecast and $17 billion less than what it was going to be but for the fiscal reform program that this government put in place, but for the choices that we made to undertake an overhaul of the state’s balance sheet and position this state for future growth, just as we are. Because this government had the courage to make those decisions, that means that the interest expense that will be shown is $492 million lower--$492 million. What is the dividend of the hard work that this government has done in reforming the state’s balance sheet, in putting forward a budget strategy that was for the long term and not for the short term, that was not about the electoral cycle but about the life cycle of this economy and this state? The fact is that debt is $17 billion lower, and that is the quantum--that is the quantification--of what we have done.

What is the sum total of what those on the opposite side have offered? The answer is zero. So, yes, there will be this afternoon presented to this House a budget that looks to the future, a budget that is not about the next election but about the decades ahead. What the people of Queensland want to see from this parliament this week is a real, fair dinkum economic debate. The Tony Abbott idolisers on the other side only want to knock and criticise. They are empty vessels who only want to engage in puffery and rhetoric, the sort of political strategy of ‘I’ll huff and I’ll puff and I’ll blow your house down’. Well, enough of the puffery. Enough of the hot air.

The time has come for the people on the other side to stand up and say what are the choices they will make. What are the things that they will do? What are the things that they will not do? Let it out. Spell it out. Put it out with the detail, because at this point in time here is a number that should be of interest to every member of this House and indeed to the people around Queensland, and that is the number of policies that the LNP has released, costed and put into the public arena. What is that number? It is zero! How many ideas does it have for the future of Queensland? Zero! What is the difference in this state budget compared to the previous forecast? $17 billion lower in debt because this government had the courage, the foresight and the fortitude to implement a fiscal reform program like good Labor governments do--the sort of thing we never see from indolent tory governments without ideas, without something to propose and only ever opposing.

Mr SEENEY: My question without notice is also to the Treasurer. I refer to the Treasurer’s comments when he described the Brisbane City Council as being broke and its budget as a horror budget even though the council’s interest payments will peak at three per cent of council’s income and the council’s budget is in surplus. I contrast that to the Treasurer’s comments on TV last night when he said that in his budget interest payments would be nine per cent of the state’s income and the budget would have a deficit of $2 billion, and I ask: how can the Treasurer continue to deny that the Brisbane City Council is in a much stronger financial position than the state of Queensland under his financial management as the worst state Treasurer in Australia?

Mr FRASER: I thank the Leader of the Opposition for that channelled question as the voice of the absent leader of the LNP. I can only look forward with delight to what is going to happen on Thursday, because I am sure there will be a nice little Pride of Erin with the Leader of the Opposition in this place and the LNP leader as they seek to respond to a budget, and respond they should.

Let me make this point about the Brisbane City Council, which handed down its budget last week: what happens to its debt forecast? It goes up by 50 per cent. If the Brisbane City Council has so much money and is so well run, why is it that in the Brisbane City Council budget papers there is no fessing up? Nowhere can you find how much the Go Between Bridge is costing the ratepayers of Brisbane each and every year. No, it is not there. What is the detail of the CityCycle scheme? Is that revealed in the budget of the Brisbane City Council? No, it is not contained in there.

So perhaps the budget reply on Thursday, delivered by the Leader of the Opposition in this place on behalf of the muppet at the top, might just tell us about the Campbell Newman tax plan to bail out the RiverCity tunnel, where he lost $774 million of ratepayers’ money. It might tell us about the Campbell Newman tax plan to bail out his cycle scheme that is rapidly going bankrupt. It might tell us about the Campbell Newman tax plan to bail out the Go Between Bridge.

Each and every time Campbell Newman has gone near building infrastructure or has undertaken any project, what has happened? There has been a massive cost blow-out. The Go Between Bridge is going broke and the CityCycle scheme is going broke, yet these people want to put him in charge of the whole state. People in cities right around Queensland should quiver in fear. They should quiver in anticipation of just what Campbell Newman might do to communities right around the state of Queensland if we ever have the misfortune of him sitting in this place and putting forward ideas, because so far he does not have one idea, one plan or one thing to say other than empty rhetoric, hot air, slogans and chanting.

From today it is ‘game on’ when the state budget gets handed down. Laid out in full--in detail--will be an economic plan for the future. The clock will be ticking for Campbell Newman to finally go beyond the slogans, to go beyond the rhetoric and to put forward a policy, to put forward a plan. That is the debate Queensland deserves to have.

Ms GRACE: My question without notice is to the Premier. Each year during Queensland Week we honour those Queenslanders who have made significant contributions to our great state. Can the Premier update the House on the latest additions to the Queensland Greats list?

Ms BLIGH:
I thank the honourable member for the question. She would know very well that the very fine Roma Street Parkland in her electorate is home to the honour wall that celebrates--
Mr Schwarten: Built by a Labor government.

Ms BLIGH: I take that interjection from the member for Rockhampton. They are wonderful parklands built by a Labor government and home to an honour wall that commemorates Queensland Greats. There have been recipients of the award in Queensland Week every year for 11 years now. There are now 50 Queensland Greats and a number of Queensland institutions that have been recognised.

This year we saw another five individuals and one organisation receive this honour. I was very pleased to make the awards this year to a number of people: firstly, to people who have been prominent in community activities and who are well known as business leaders--and Dr Betty Byrne Henderson AM is very well known to this House. I was also very pleased to see a very strong regional series of nominations this year, with George Chapman AO from Cairns--I think George is the first non-Indigenous person from Far North Queensland to be awarded--and Graham Jackson OAM from Townsville. All three people are very prominent business leaders and they use their business ability to then go on to make very significant contributions in a number of community organisations.
Out of the business sector and on to the sporting fields, it was a great honour to yet again recognise the sporting prowess of our rugby league legend Wally Lewis.
A government member: A great Valleys player.

Ms BLIGH:
I think he did a bit more after he played for Valleys. As we get ready for the second State of Origin game, we all know the contribution that Wally Lewis has made to football and sport in Queensland, but he is also a great ambassador for the Hear and Say Centre and for people with hearing loss, and I was very pleased that many of them were there to see him get his award. I was also very pleased to see a Queenslander who has made a very important, prominent name for himself on the national stage as one of the great journalists of our time, that is, Kerry O’Brien. I know that Kerry was very honoured to be recognised by his home state in this way.

When it comes to recognising a Queensland Great institution, I could think of no better year than this year to see our marvellous SES officers awarded as the 2011 Queensland Great organisation. These are 6,800 volunteer members who are there when we need them on the front line. I join with the Minister for Police in congratulating them again and I am very pleased to see them recognised. I am also pleased to see the launch of a new SES recruitment campaign. Thousands of people came out during our disasters to help. We have a job for them if they want to do it again.

Mr NICHOLLS: My question is to the Treasurer. How much extra will Queenslanders be paying next year for electricity, for water, for registration and for fuel even if the ambulance levy, worth $109 a year, is removed in today’s budget? Why should Queenslanders believe that they will be any better off under this budget, given the increases in taxes and charges they have endured over the past three years?

Mr FRASER: I thank the shadow Treasurer for the question. What we can expect to see this afternoon from this government is a budget that makes choices. It is one that owns up to the fact that the task of government requires people to front up with the policy choices, to say what it is they are going to do, what it is they are not going to do and how they are going to do it. It is a budget that is going to be honest with the people of Queensland. It is a budget that is going to tell it like it is. It is a budget that is going to respect the people of Queensland and their ability to see that governments have to make choices.

It will go beyond the political tactic of the LNP in this parliament, which is to stand up and pretend that there are never choices to be made, to stand up and pretend that it can do everything without ever spelling out what it is it is going to do, that there is some magic pot over there that it dips into at every point in time and that it is able to do whatever it wants at every point in time. This budget makes clear choices about what it is that we as a government believe in, the policies that we are going to pursue, the issues that we are going to address and the people we want to assist--those in our community who are doing it the toughest, and they are in particular those who are on fixed incomes, our pensioners, who we know right around Australia have been put under pressure because of the nature of the economy.

Therefore, we are going to see from this government choices made that lay out in detail a plan. I bet that plan will stand in stark contrast to what we are going to see on Thursday. That will just be a Tony Abbott channelling exercise--walking in here offering only criticism, offering only negativity, offering only opposition and not one single proposition. It remains to be seen what we will get from the LNP on the other side of the House--those indolent members of the opposition who have not laid a finger near a policy piece of work for the more than two years that we have been in this parliament.

What should the people of Queensland look for on Thursday? They should look for a proposal. They should look for a scintilla of an idea. Can they scratch it out on a piece of paper? Can they get out the old chalkboard and write out what it might be? My prediction is that after the budget reply speech in here on Thursday is over, all we will be left with is extra greenhouse gases and the hot air and wind of people who are bereft of ideas, bereft of policy proposals, without a clue, without an ability to put forward a policy proposal. Then the people of Queensland on Thursday night can look at what this government proposes--what this government says it is going to do, the choices it is going to make, the way it is going to do it, the detail of it, the hard numbers, owning up to the reality, charting a course for the future--and then look at what they will get from the other side, which is nought, zero, zip--zero policies, zero ideas and zero credibility.
Mr WATT: My question is directed to the Premier. Can the Premier advise the House how the government is building a greener, stronger and more sustainable future for Queensland?

Ms BLIGH: I thank the honourable member for the question and I know of his interest in this area. I am pleased to be able to advise the House of some of the great work that is happening right across Queensland by businesses that are accepting the science on climate change and want to be part of the solution. We have people who are doing terrific work. That is why I was very pleased on Friday night to join with the environment minister, Kate Jones, and 500 businesses, schools and community organisations to recognise people who have chalked up some very significant sustainability achievements. Everyone there was what I would call a practical environmentalist: someone who in their own business is changing their work practices to reduce their impact on the planet, someone who is helping others do it or, in some cases, people who are inventing products that will actually help the world.

There were some world-beating innovations there. For example, the Toowoomba based company known to many people here, Wagners, was named overall winner for its new eco-friendly concrete.
