Concrete is not the first thing one thinks of when thinking about a greener future, but the cement industry is responsible for five per cent of the world’s emissions. What Wagners has done is defy convention by using two waste bioproducts, blast furnace slag and fly ash, to develop an innovative alternative to traditional carbon intensive Portland cement. It is called Earth Friendly Concrete. It is the same, if not better, with engineering and construction properties as good as traditional concrete, but it saves 9.2 tonnes of CO 2 emissions per 300 square metre slab and produces 80 to 90 per cent lower CO 2 emissions than its traditional alternative.

If all house slabs built every year in Queensland were made from this Wagners product it could save up to 270,000 tonnes of greenhouse gas emissions. That is a remarkable achievement and it is happening right here in regional Queensland. It is a great Toowoomba family company that cares not only about its employees and its business bottom line but is proving through efforts like this that it cares about the planet, and I take my hat off to it.

At the awards there were 154 nominees, 36 finalists and 11 category winners. There were very strong nominations this year from the school sector which I think is a great credit to school leaders, principals and teachers taking young people on this journey with them from the youngest of ages in both the state and non-state sectors of schooling.

I am very pleased to take the opportunity today to congratulate the Minister for Environment. These awards were started last year. They are a way of recognising those businesses in Queensland that are not only doing something terrific in their own business but also potentially offering something to the world. The product that I have outlined from Wagners could well be one of our next big exports and I look forward to working with that company to bring it to reality.

Mr GIBSON: My question is to the Treasurer. Given federal Labor’s support for a great big new carbon tax starting in 2012 and the Treasurer’s support for Labor’s big new carbon tax, has the budget been framed to include the impacts of the introduction of Labor’s carbon tax and if not how can anyone believe the slick forecasts that this budget contains?

Mr FRASER: I thank the shadow minister for his question. I trust that his call out into the wild has been answered. In recent weeks he sent out a memo inviting anybody who might be able to volunteer to help him read the budget papers. He finds it a little bit hard to go through the budget papers so he put the call out. I trust that some helpful soul has appeared and wandered up to provide a little bit of assistance to the member for Gympie to go through the budget papers and explain them to him. I am a little bit busy for the rest of the day but I would be happy to sit down and take him through some of the finer points in the budget if he finds that offer helpful.

Let me say that the budget this afternoon will not include any modelling on the Campbell Newman tunnel bailout tax, it will not include any modelling on the Campbell Newman CityCycle bailout tax, it will not include any modelling on the Campbell Newman Go Between Bridge bailout tax, it will not include any modelling on the Campbell Newman ‘syphon the money off into South-East Queensland and deny the regions secret plan’ tax and it will not include modelling on the Campbell Newman great big tax to fund all the promises I am making without a single scintilla of policy or costings. What it will do is set out in detail what it is this government stands for, the choices we make and our vision for the future. Let us be clear about it. There is a proposal in this nation right now, a debate, there is no legislation in a parliament--
Opposition members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Stop the clock. Those on my left!

Mr FRASER: There is a proposal. It is a proposal to front up to the reality of climate change. Even those climate change deniers on the other side, even just the driest of economic rushes on the other side, should see the rationality in pricing a scarce resource. Those on the opposite side cannot have it both ways. They cannot have Campbell Newman out there on the weekend talking about the ClimateSmart Home Service as gizmos when he co-funded it as Lord Mayor. What rank hypocrisy is that? He wants to say in Ashgrove, ‘Dear people of Ashgrove, I support climate change. I believe in the science.’ Then he wants to run around in regional Queensland saying, ‘I don’t believe in climate change. I don’t believe in the science. All of this is a Labor conspiracy.’ The time will come--and the time comes from 2.30 this afternoon--when it is game on for a real fair dinkum policy debate. If Campbell Newman was fair dinkum he would stand up and say once and for all whether he believes in climate change and if he does not I am sure there are about 30,000 people in Ashgrove who would love to hear why not.

Mrs ATTWOOD: My question is to the Deputy Premier and Attorney-General, Minister for Local Government and Special Minister of State. Can the Deputy Premier please update the House on the planning work the Bligh government is doing to help Queensland communities recover from the devastating summer floods?

Mr LUCAS: Last week on 7 June I had the honour to represent the Premier at Grantham, together with local mayor Steve Jones and Graham Newton from the Queensland Reconstruction Authority, and to turn the first sod on a very exciting new housing development. Those who are familiar with Grantham would know that the hamlet of Grantham sits down in the valley--as hamlets often do--and is surrounded by farmland. Shortly after the flood event I was in Grantham with the mayor and he spoke to me about his vision of relocating the town from the low ground up to the high ground. I do not claim to be an expert on matters of agricultural soil or primary production, but it is quite clear that in most instances in agricultural terms the good quality soil tends to be alluvial and down in the river flats and the poorer quality soil tends to be on the ridges. Additionally, there is also the advantage that on the ridges, which are elevated from flood land, there are also nicer views. Therefore, all other things being equal, in farming country in the Lockyer Valley, which of course is very high quality farming country, the ability to develop the land on the hills is a win-win.

Through the Queensland Reconstruction Authority, in cooperation with the council--as it is a council project--we are identifying a very significant amount of land for the voluntary relocation of people from Grantham from the parts affected by flood and also very significantly growing it further to provide further sustainable mass for the people in Grantham. These new blocks will be kerbed and channelled, they will have parkland, many of them will be sewered although some of them will be septic depending on the size of the particular block. In an Australian first, it is actually building back the community better. It was a very good idea from the Lockyer Valley Regional Council and the mayor. That this can be done about four months post the flood event really does show the ability of the Queensland Reconstruction Authority to get on with the job of getting through those approvals. Additionally, the temporary local planning instrument endorsed also allows that to be facilitated.

Speaking of local governments and temporary local planning instruments, through my department I have also worked with both the Ipswich City Council and the Brisbane City Council on temporary local planning instruments to deal with flooding issues pending the resolution and further inquiry of those issues through the flood commissions of inquiry. In relation to Brisbane and Ipswich, they look at interim standards that are appropriate in those communities pending these matters being resolved. That is important because the business of getting on with building and redoing things must not wait until the conclusion of the royal commission. This is about working to get very good outcomes for people in these communities and working cooperatively to get them as soon as possible. I thank the councils for their cooperation.

Mr BLEIJIE: My question is to the Treasurer. I refer to claims made by the Treasurer on 26 July 2010 that Queensland was heading in the right direction, noting one report that ‘the next few years should see Queensland start to muscle its way back towards the top of the state growth league ladder’. Given that since then CommSec, the Centre for Independent Studies and the IPA say the Queensland economy has slipped from second last to last in the economic league table, how can Queenslanders believe anything the Treasurer promises for the future?

Mr FRASER: I thank the member for Kawana for his question. It ranks right up there with the time the member for Southern Downs accused this parliament of not being aware of a global financial crisis. A few things happened while you were asleep. One of those things is that in this state there was a natural disaster of gigantic proportions which has massively impacted on the economy. Anyone--
Opposition members interjected.
Mr FRASER: Those on the other side want me to forecast a tax that does not exist, but they do not want to take account of a natural disaster that actually happened.
Opposition members interjected.

Mr SPEAKER: Order! Stop the clock. Treasurer, resume your seat. Member for Clayfield, you have had a pretty good go this morning. I warn you now under 253A(1). Those on my left, you have asked the Treasurer a question and the Treasurer is answering the question. It may not be the answer you want, but I am taking it that it is in the spirit in which it was asked.

Mr FRASER: I do hope the shadow Treasurer can be here for the speech this afternoon. Those on the other side want me to model a tax that does not exist, but they do not want to take account of natural disasters that actually happened. That is the central proposition of the last couple of questions.

Over the past 12 months, those on the opposite side have taken every opportunity to talk down the Queensland economy. They want to come in here and use right-wing think tanks like the Centre for Independent Studies, which is probably a misnomer, and the Institute of Public Affairs, which is that very balanced institution that promotes the most right-wing extreme agenda and is out there cheering from the sidelines as Barry O’Farrell trashes workers’ rights in New South Wales and as they traduce the rights of trade union movements in the state of New South Wales. If they want to hold up the Centre for Independent Studies and the Institute of Public Affairs as their hallmark, so be it. Other than that, they want to use a stockbroking firm, yet it is well on the public record the exceptions that have been taken, not just by me but by other treasurers around the state, to the methodology of CommSec. Of course, that has forced them to make a change to their methodology as they acknowledged that the way they were assessing economies was in fact open to question and should change.

Last year it was predicted that there would be business investment growth of nine per cent in the Queensland economy. Those naysayers on the other side said that people could not believe that there would be business investment this year. Each and every day since then they have done their level best to talk it down. It turns out that last year there was not nine per cent business investment growth in this state; there was 13 per cent business investment growth in this state. More than anything else, that tells us what we need to know; that is, through the past 12 months, despite the natural disasters, despite the shadow Treasurer and various leaders of the opposition and the rest of the naysayers talking down business, talking down Queensland and talking down the Queensland economy, business has spoken with the only language that counts, by investing money in the state of Queensland, investing in private sector investment and driving prosperity. That is exactly what is occurring, despite the very best efforts of those opposite to talk it down.
Ms STONE: My question without notice is to the Treasurer and Minister for State Development and Trade. Can the Treasurer update the House on the recently released national accounts data?

Mr FRASER: I thank the member for Springwood for her question and for her advocacy for her electorate. She is a tireless advocate for works on the Pacific Motorway and work in her community. She works closely with all local community organisations such as those at the local community centre. I pay tribute to the work that she does in the parliament on behalf of the people of Springwood. The honourable member also supports strong economic policies that are about generating jobs, growth and investment.

Since the parliament last sat, the ABS has released the national accounts. As I intimated earlier, they tell a story in facts presented by the Australian Bureau of Statistics. Those facts might be denied by those on the other side, who only want to read hegemony from institutions like the Institute of Public Affairs. However, what do the facts show? What does the ABS say about what occurred in the Queensland economy versus the national economy in the March quarter, which was the quarter hardest hit by natural disasters? In the March quarter, in Queensland business investment increased by 10.5 per cent for the year, and that was driven by investment in machinery and equipment of more than 12 per cent and in engineering construction of more than 15 per cent. How does that compare to Australia? In the same time frame, business investment was seven per cent. Business investment was going ahead in Queensland through the year to the March quarter, which included the natural disasters, at a rate ahead of the nation.

Those opposite might want to pick up on their favourite tory magazines, their favourite right-wing shock jocks and their favourite right-wing policy document writers. In fact, they could probably pick up a few tips on how to write something down. However, ultimately, when it comes down to the judge and jury, when it comes down to the independent referee, when it comes down to the independent umpire, the statistics from the ABS say that business investment increased through the quarter of the natural disasters at a rate ahead of the rest of the country. This afternoon the budget will show that locked-in business investment. It will show that great wave and surge of investment, which is ready to course through the Queensland economy and which is going to deliver a new era of prosperity to this state.

The only thing we are at risk from is the policy-free zone of the people opposite. They do not have a single idea, a single policy or a single proposal to put forward. Should they ever drag their knuckles across the chamber and sit on this side of the House, Queensland’s economic recovery will be at risk. However, while this government, which has the courage and the foresight to plan for the future, drives the economy into the future, we will continue to see investment grow. The only risk to the Queensland economic recovery is if Campbell Newman, his policy-free zone and his policy-free team end up on this side of the chamber.

Mr EMERSON: My question is to the Treasurer. I refer to the fact that, after years and years of the LNP pushing, the community ambulance cover levy will be removed by a desperate Labor Party in the budget today. Given that this is a cynical vote-buying exercise by the Treasurer, who promised not to impose a fuel tax, can Queenslanders have any confidence that the ambulance levy will not be replaced with a new tax after the election?

Mr FRASER: Not if the LNP is elected, because we know that they are out there, whispering around the various communities of Queensland--hoping that no-one ever picks them up on it--that they are going to fix everything. They are out there saying that they are going to do everything, they are going to build everything, they are going to deliver everything, they are going to give lollies to every child, they are going to give a bike to every child, they are going to make sure that everyone who is a little bit grumpy on a Thursday night gets a free ticket to the footy on Friday. They are going to do it all, but how are they going to do it? They have not said!

The risk to the back pockets of Queenslanders does not come from this government, which is going to set out in full detail a whole agenda for economic recovery. We will set out our policy choices in full detail and we will set out all the numbers. It will be a good read and I recommend it to those opposite, including the member for Gympie. It will be a good read that grasps the opportunities, that looks at what is going to happen next and makes the choices. The only risk to the Queensland economy is Campbell Newman’s sloganeering, rhetoric and reckless promises to do everything but cost nothing, to promise everything but put out no policies to say how he is going to do it. If they end up on this side of the chamber, woe betide the people of Queensland, the Queensland state budget and the Queensland economy.

After all, this person proposed to build a tunnel that he said would cost $850 million. Then he said it could cost $1 billion. Then he said it would cost $2 billion-plus. Then it was going to cost $2 billion-plus-plus. It ended up costing $3 billion. This is the person who they say is going to manage the state’s finances? He is the person who tripled the cost of a tunnel that is now in receivership. What a financial genius that man must be! He is a financial genius who had a plan to build a Northern Link tunnel. So good was his plan that he had to bring his cup to the Queensland Treasury and ask me to loan him the money. He flew around the world, rattling the tin and asking people to pitch in for the Northern Link tunnel, but what did he come back with? An empty cup! What did he do? He put it on the tick of the ratepayer, because his ego would not let him go back. His ego drove him forward. In the end, the ratepayers of Queensland and Brisbane have an enduring legacy because Campbell Newman’s multibillion dollar tunnel dream is turning into a tunnel nightmare and his ego would not allow him to walk backwards and face up to the reality. I say to the people of Queensland: if you want someone who is going to triple infrastructure costs, does not know how to manage a budget and as soon as it gets tough does a cut-and-run, you should put your mark on Campbell Newman. However, if you want someone who will stand up, tell it like it is and look to the future, then vote Labor.

Mr SPEAKER: May I say to both sides of the House that if the line of questioning is such that it is meant to elicit a response from the person being questioned, that is entirely what is going to happen. You can barely blame the person being questioned for then turning it back. What I am after is not so much dedicated silence but at least to hear the answer. I would say to both sides: if you do not want that sort of response then do not ask the loaded question.

Mr WENDT: My question is to the Minister for Police, Corrective Services and Emergency Services. Can the minister advise the House about the strict monitoring and compliance regime applied by Corrective Services to those persons subjected to the Dangerous Prisoners (Sexual Offenders) Act.

Mr ROBERTS: I thank the member for the question and for the support and interest he shows in Corrective Services operations and probation and parole in his electorate. The Labor government does take very seriously the responsibility we have to ensure that dangerous sex offenders are held accountable for their crimes and, if they are released into the community, are supervised appropriately. We need to remind the House again that it was a Labor government that introduced the Dangerous Prisoners (Sexual Offenders) Act, which provides the courts with an opportunity to either keep high-risk offenders in jail beyond their sentence or issue appropriate supervision orders in the community. The Queensland government also introduced the child sex offender register, in conjunction with other states, which enables the monitoring of the whereabouts of child sex offenders under the ANCOR register.

Our laws are as tough as they can get. They are at the limit of constitutionality. They have been challenged in the High Court. They have been criticised severely by the United Nations. But they are tough and they provide the appropriate levels of control and supervision of offenders. Interestingly enough, I have also received a letter of complaint from an LNP member about how tough our laws are, particularly in relation to an ANCOR offender who last year was breached for failing to comply with his annual reporting requirements. Not only have we had criticism from the High Court and the United Nations; we have also had criticism from an LNP member who was representing one of his constituents.

In addition to the ability for courts to keep people in jail, offenders can be put on supervision orders with up to 50 or 60 conditions. If they breach those DPSO orders, QCS gives them no quarter and they are brought back before the courts if necessary. Members would by aware of recent media coverage which demonstrates how tough QCS is. An RTI application showed that in the 13 months to February 2011, 52 offenders were breached from a total of 154 contraventions. Some of those contraventions were serious; others on the face of it may not seem to be that serious. However, QCS treats them seriously--for example, reporting late to a corrective services officer for an appointment, being next door at a neighbour’s house watching the footy instead of being in their own home, making an unauthorised phone call and failing to meet a curfew. They are all examples of how tough Queensland Corrective Services is.
As members are aware, the government has announced that it will be introducing GPS monitoring for sex offenders, costing around $14 million over four years.
An opposition member: That was a good idea. Did you think of that yourself?
Mr ROBERTS: The LNP does not know whether it is coming or going on this issue.
Mr Nicholls: Come on!

Mr ROBERTS: On 3 June, the member for Clayfield said on radio that the LNP was looking into the issue and three days later he said that it had always been their policy. It is a Labor government that has taken the tough steps to introduce appropriate legislation to either keep offenders in jail or have them appropriately supervised, and it is a Labor government that will be introducing GPS monitoring to assist that regime.

Mr LANGBROEK: My question without notice is to the Minister for Police, Corrective Services and Emergency Services. Given the well-publicised increase in crime across Queensland, can the minister give an assurance that there will be funding for new police initiatives in today’s budget?

Mr ROBERTS: I thank the member for the question. It is obvious that he does not read the police annual statistical review. That review shows very clearly that for the ninth consecutive year crime rates in Queensland are declining. Indeed, what is that a result of? It is a result of this Labor government resourcing the Police Service to levels where it can actually get out there and proactively address crime.

Let us go back to the Fitzgerald inquiry. One of the key complaints about the National Party government was low police numbers--low resourcing of the Police Service leading to high crime rates. Since Labor has been in office there has been significant investment in police resources including a significant improvement in the police-to-population ratio. Under the Liberal-National Party government there was one police officer for every 507 people. We have significantly reduced that to around one police officer for every 430-odd people.

Crime rates in Queensland have been reducing over the last 10 years under this Labor government. The rate of property offences is down around 48 per cent. More than 30,000 fewer homes and businesses are broken into today than 10 years ago. That is a result of increased resources to the Police Service and proactive policing. The rate of offences against the person has reduced by around 20 per cent across Queensland. All of these reductions are due to improved resourcing for the Police Service.

I am proud of the support that the Queensland Labor government has given to the Police Service. This budget will continue a number of measures that have been in place for some time and also, as has been announced, obviously increase resources. As I have indicated, the opposition is in denial about what is happening with crime in Queensland. Of course there are concerns about spikes in crime rates in particular categories, and I acknowledge in particular some of the issues which have been experienced on the Gold Coast. We have been dealing with that issue.

The facts speak for themselves. In particular, over the last 10 years the trend rates for crime in Queensland have been significantly reducing. I repeat: there has been a 48 per cent reduction in the rate of property crime and around a 20 per cent reduction in offences against the person. All of this is due to proactive, professional policing and also due to the resources that the Labor government has been giving the Police Service.

Mrs KIERNAN: My question is to the Minister for Agriculture, Food and Regional Economies. Given the federal government’s decision and the concern of producers in my electorate with regard to live exports, can the minister please update the House on the implications for Queensland producers of the suspension of live exports to Indonesia?

Mr MULHERIN: I thank the honourable member for Mount Isa for her question. I know of her concerns not only for the primary producers--the cattlemen out in that area who really care for their livestock--but also for the communities in which that industry operates--the small country towns that will be impacted by the federal government decision. As members know, on 8 June the federal government imposed a suspension of the live cattle trade to Indonesia. The live cattle trade here in Queensland is worth about $100 million per year. Up to 200,000 head of cattle are exported yearly to Indonesia. While the suspension of live exports to Indonesia will directly impact on mainly producers in the north of the state, clearly the ramifications of this suspension will be felt much more widely.

The Queensland government is working to support the cattle industry. The Queensland Live Cattle Export Task Force has been established to deal with the specific issues whilst the trade has been suspended. The task force will include representatives from AgForce, large pastoralists and the processing sector. It will work on identifying market options for stranded cattle, provide assistance to affected producers and work with the Commonwealth government to ensure reinstatement of trade. In conjunction with AgForce, we will also be conducting a major livestock industry forum in Mount Isa in the coming weeks to discuss the current situation. The forum will be open to all sectors of the industry. A farm financial counselling service has been made available to businesses affected by this decision.

Discussions will shortly commence with the Department of Transport and Main Roads, along with the industry, on the possible lifting of road transport permits to assist in the movement of cattle into feedlots in other parts of the state. The Queensland government will work with the industry to respond to the Australian government’s independent supply chain review, which is being headed up by a former ambassador to Indonesia, Mr Bill Farmer. We want to make sure that this review is a priority so that the recommencement of live cattle exports can occur. We recognise that Indonesia is a key export market for Queensland cattle. However, we must ensure that we have safeguards in place so that the industry can move forward with confidence in the overseas supply chain.

Mr CRIPPS: My question without notice is to the Minister for Agriculture, Food and Regional Economies. I refer to the Gillard Labor government’s decision to suspend the live cattle trade from Australia to Indonesia, undermining the $100 million a year trade. I note the answer of the Minister for Agriculture, Food and Regional Economies to the question from the member for Mount Isa and the characteristic response of the Bligh Labor government to establish a committee to address serious issues. When will the Bligh Labor government stand up for Queensland’s cattle industry and the 1,200 workers who rely on the live cattle trade for their livelihoods to ensure that the Gillard Labor government takes responsibility for compensating affected industry participants and moves to re-establish a fully identifiable and traceable supply chain that meets Australia’s animal welfare expectations?

Mr MULHERIN: I thank the honourable member for the question. This is not the first time that suspensions have been put in place for the export of live animals to markets in different parts of the world. Those suspensions have been put in place because of public outrage in relation to the way animals have been treated. Previously the Howard government put a ban on live sheep exports because of those issues--we could not guarantee, with the supply chain, that at the end point those animals would be treated with the highest animal welfare standards that we have come to expect here in Australia.

AgForce has met with me and the Premier. It was the suggestion of AgForce to set up a task force to develop responses particularly to Queensland, and that is what we have done. We have established a task force at the request of AgForce. I make that clear: AgForce asked for this task force. That is what we have done. This task force will then feed into the Australian government’s industry-government review of the supply chain. The industry will also participate in our weekly hook-up with the Northern Territory, Western Australia and Queensland governments in relation to the matters at hand.

The federal government has imposed this ban and it will continue to negotiate with industry around the industry’s issues. It has set up this overarching industry-government review, headed by Mr Bill Farmer. There are also a number of subcommittees that will look at broader issues. We will continue to work with AgForce and larger pastoral companies. We have responded to needs, and we will be organising a forum at Mount Isa with AgForce and other large pastoral groups in the next couple of weeks so that people will have the opportunity to bring their issues to us so that we can forward them to the national process.

We want to see that this trade is reinstated as quickly as possible, but we need to have confidence that the supply chain is of the highest standard to ensure that Australian cattle are treated appropriately at the end point of processing. As I have said, this is not the first time that a federal government has imposed bans on the live export of animals. The Howard government did it on two occasions. From memory, when it put a ban on the trade of sheep into Egypt, that ban lasted for 12 months. It is hopeful that this trade will be reinstated within six months. The view of those opposite is that it is okay for the tories to put a ban on the export of live animals but it is bad for a Labor government to do the same.
Mrs SULLIVAN: My question without notice is to the Minister for Main Roads, Fisheries and Marine Infrastructure. Can the minister inform the House about federal funding for the Bruce Highway?

Mr WALLACE: I thank the member for Pumicestone for the question. She knows the importance of the Bruce Highway--a vital link up and down the Queensland coastline. The Bruce Highway is a federally funded road, and a big increase in federal funds over many years is needed to bring it up to a reasonable standard. Unfortunately, we are playing some catch up after 12 years of neglect by the Howard government. Let us not forget that many of those members opposite were here in this place cheering on the Howard government during those 12 years of neglect. It is interesting to look at the figures. Under the Howard government, on average the Bruce Highway received an insulting $100 million a year for roadworks. Let us compare that to Labor--$480 million a year under Labor, nearly a fivefold increase under Labor.

So I was perplexed--I was surprised--by the response I received when I recently put out a press release questioning the bona fides of the Leader of the Opposition when it comes to fixing the Bruce Highway. He was up in North Queensland talking about it. But let us not forget that he was in this place for seven years cheering on the Howard government. What did he do to twist the Howard government’s arm on the Bruce? What did he do? Absolutely nothing. In fact the question needs to be asked: why was that old warhorse who did nothing about the Bruce for seven years talking about the Bruce Highway?

Unfortunately, he took exception to my media release and put out his own. The LNP hard man said that I was guilty of a ‘childish personal attack’. And that is coming from the member for Callide--a ‘childish personal attack’! Unfortunately, it seems the member for Callide has caught ‘Claytons’ Campbell’s double disease--a thin skin and a glass jaw. Perhaps in a hissy fit the member for Callide’s 9 June press release has been removed from the LNP website. That is why I table a copy today for posterity so that all in the House can see it.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Press release, dated 9 June 2011, from the Leader of the Opposition entitled ‘Memo to Craig Wallace: Focus on your job and forget childish, personal attacks’ [ 4630 ].
XML.Hansard-Body: But we should not be surprised that they are trying to hide. The RACQ put out a report about the state’s roads and sure enough the Bruce Highway was there, highlighting the neglect of the Howard government. Surprise, surprise! Five of the 10 worst local government roads were in the Brisbane City Council’s area. I am not surprised. Why were half of the roads in the Brisbane City Council’s area? Because ‘Claytons’ Campbell starved suburban roads of funding to fund his tunnel folly, and he would do the same--

Mrs CUNNINGHAM: My question without notice is to the Minister for Health. Estimates are that LNG alone will create around 15,000 jobs in Gladstone. Additionally there are other contractors coming for other work. I am advised that locum contracts are being cancelled and full-time positions remain unfilled at the Gladstone Hospital. Will the minister give the people of the Gladstone electorate an assurance that the Gladstone Hospital will employ the staff required to provide the level of service needed to meet this community growth?

Mr WILSON: I thank the honourable member for the question. It is an important question about planning in our various regions and in particular in Gladstone. As I have indicated both privately to the member and publicly on other occasions, a significant body of service planning work is being done by Queensland Health for not only Gladstone but the broader surrounding area. It is proposed that we will be able to provide some answers and responses to the questions that the member and many others have asked in terms of long-term planning before the end of this year.

It is important that we get the planning right. There is a major development taking place throughout the whole of Queensland; it is not just limited to LNG in Gladstone and the Surat Basin. We want to make sure that the long-term planning, not just around health but other vital government services, is robust and takes into account all of the contemporary knowledge and information that we have about the long-term population growth and the way in which the industry will develop not only in Gladstone but in the surrounding region. We need to do that to ensure that we get the planning right.
Mrs Cunningham interjected.

Mr WILSON: It is a significant issue. The member has asked a serious question and the assurance I give her is that that planning work will conclude before the end of this year so that we can provide the answers to some of these important questions for the immediate term and for the longer term.

Ms BOYLE: My question is to the Minister for Environment and Resource Management. Will the minister please advise the House how Queensland’s cane farmers are helping to protect the Great Barrier Reef?

Ms JONES: I thank the honourable member for her question. I think everybody in this House knows just how passionate the member for Cairns is when it comes to protecting the Great Barrier Reef and how important the Great Barrier Reef is to Queensland’s economy, as it supports up to 65,000 jobs and a $5 billion tourism industry. That is why when the scientific consensus report was released in late 2008 we decided as a state government that we needed to take action to protect the Great Barrier Reef. I had the great honour and responsibility of introducing into this House landmark legislation that does just that. It addresses some of the key threats to the Great Barrier Reef and its future.

This report showed that, despite seeing significant dollars invested into voluntary measures by the federal government over a long period of time--coming on the back of a significant agreement signed by the then Prime Minister of the country, John Howard, and the Premier of Queensland at the time, Peter Beattie--we were seeing nutrient, sediment and pesticide levels in the Great Barrier Reef that were still extremely high, and these came from intensive agriculture in the main. We have actually seen pesticides some 60 kilometres offshore. This new legislation protects the Great Barrier Reef from those threats. We are getting real action, with over 85 per cent of farmers who are covered by this legislation complying with the environmental risk management plan.

What we have seen once again is the new leader of the LNP, the electoral leader, promising one thing to one group of people and saying another thing to another group. He went to Proserpine recently, and what did he say to the cane farmers at Proserpine? ‘We’re going to scrap that legislation.’ What did he then turn around and say to the tourism businesses in Airlie Beach? ‘We’re going to get more people here to look at the Great Barrier Reef.’ Once again we are showing that he does not want to support the legislation which protects the Great Barrier Reef but he promises to bring more people from Asia to come and see the Great Barrier Reef--a reef that will have no future.
Mr Fraser: The further from the Ashgrove PO, the more redneck he is.

Ms JONES: I take the interjection from the Treasurer, because in the same week he wrote a letter to the people of Ashgrove saying that he is going to protect the environment. This is a man who will do or say anything.

The biggest threats to the Great Barrier Reef are poor water quality and climate change. We announced this week that we will spend another $60 million expanding the ClimateSmart Home Service so that more than one in four Queensland households can play their part in reducing emissions. This is a program that the former Lord Mayor of Brisbane not only supported but also funded. He used ratepayers’ dollars to implement this program in Brisbane households, but now that he is spending time with the National Party in Queensland he is calling it a waste of taxpayers’ dollars and gizmos and gadgets. This is a man who will do and say anything, who does not believe in protecting the environment and who does not believe in climate change.

Ms DAVIS: My question is to the Minister for Child Safety and Minister for Sport. How can the minister guarantee that children are receiving the attention they need or that his department is operating efficiently when non-government child safety agencies aim for case loads of 12 or 13 cases per officer compared to his department’s average of 22.4 cases per officer and reaching a peak of a massive 32.8 cases per officer? How can we believe anything this government says in today’s budget when it cannot even deliver improved case loads for child safety workers?
Mr SPEAKER: The minister has one minute.

Mr REEVES: I thank the honourable member for the question. It is quite an interesting question coming from that side because we are still waiting to see their policy, two years after their discussion paper was released. They do not have a policy. It does not exist, but I suppose it is a bit hard to have a policy when they have had at least three shadow ministers for child safety.

Our staff do a remarkable job every hour and every day of every week. Since 2004 we have tripled the budget and doubled the staff--and that does not include what is happening at 2.30 today. When the opposition were last in office the budget was minuscule compared to this year’s budget of $695 million--and we will wait to see what happens at 2.30 today.
Mr SPEAKER: The honourable minister’s time has expired. The time for question time has ended.

Hansard-Body.A: (Callide--LNP) (Leader of the Opposition) (11.45 am): This morning we saw why the member for Mount Coot-tha is fast becoming acknowledged as the worst state Treasurer in Australia. This morning we saw the reason the Queensland economy is in such a financial mess. This morning we saw why this government is running scared of its own financial mismanagement. This is a government that went broke in a boom. It went broke in a boom and it waits desperately for the next boom in order to break even. That is the economic management strategy that has been put in place by the member for Mount Coot-tha.

XML.Hansard-Body: Any attempt to question him on his economic management strategy results in personal abuse being thrown in all directions. Not quite sure who is to blame, he smacks everybody in sight with his personal abuse to cover his own financial failings. He is undoubtedly the worst state Treasurer in Australia and it is the people of Queensland who are suffering for that failing. The people of Queensland are suffering because the Treasurer has lost his way. He is a Treasurer who has lost his economic compass and does not know how to get out of the difficulty that his own mismanagement has brought the state into.

The budget that we will see this afternoon will be a litany of disgrace and it will be the legacy of this state Labor government. That is, this government has put the state into a financial position that generations of Queenslanders will bemoan. Generations of Queenslanders will struggle to repay the debt that continues to be accumulated, despite the fact that the government and the Treasurer embarked on an asset sales program--a deceitful asset sales program--in an attempt to pay down the debt. Well, the attempt has failed. The attempt has failed because the debt that will be projected this afternoon will be greater than what we have seen in previous years. The debt continues to grow, despite the fact that the assets have been sold. While that debt continues to grow, the interest bill that every Queenslander must shoulder also continues to grow.

A little bit of simple mathematic calculation shows that our interest payments are $595,000 every hour. I repeat: the people of Queensland will pay $595,000 every hour in interest. That is an enormous amount of money that could be put to better use. That amounts to some $14 million a day or $100 million a week in interest. The interest payments that this government has incurred on behalf of the people of Queensland could build a new school every two days. They could build a new regional hospital every week. They could build a major hospital every four weeks. They could employ 50,000 nurses, teachers and policemen and provide the sorts of services that the people of Queensland so badly need.

But instead that $595,000 an hour will be used to pay the interest on a debt that this government has run up while it desperately waits for the boom times to return. Nothing typifies the state Labor government better than its failure to manage the finances of this state. Nothing typifies its failure better than the fact that it still does not have a solution, it still does not have a plan, it still does not have anything that can provide hope to the people of Queensland that things are going to get better.

We on the other hand will develop a plan to address Labor’s failures. We are developing a plan which will give the people of Queensland some hope that there will be a solution to that monumental $85 billion worth of debt, that we in Queensland can grow the economy, that we can grow business and attempt in time to pay back that great legacy of this failed Labor government--a Labor government that has done what Labor governments always do. Labor governments always go broke. They always blow the money. They always look to blame somebody else. They always seek to find an excuse and they are never successful at managing the money, and this Labor government is a great example of that.

Hansard-Body.A: (Clayfield--LNP) (Deputy Leader of the Opposition) (11.50 am): Over the last couple of days we have seen the start of another slick spin cycle from the Treasurer and from this government. We are seeing promises of more good times just around the corner. Just around the corner we will see the sun shine--the sunlit uplands--under this Labor Party come around. But we have heard these promises before. We heard them in 2007-08 when the Premier was the Treasurer and she said that the up time was just around the corner. We heard them in 2008-09 when they said the good times are just about to happen. We heard them in 2009-10 when they said, ‘The GFC has passed us and the good times are coming. Business investment is about to boom. We are on our way back--on our way back to a surplus, on our way back to paying back debt.’ And we heard them last year in 2010-11.

XML.Hansard-Body: We heard the Treasurer say in July 2010, ‘We will be No. 1 for jobs and No. 1 for infrastructure and No. 1 for interstate migration.’ All wrong! In September 2010 he predicted a surge in business investment and private housing investment. Wrong again! As late as December last year he said, ‘We have turned the corner. We will be on our way back to the good times.’ And again he was wrong. He was wrong according to the Institute of Public Affairs.
Mr Watt interjected.
Mr NICHOLLS: He was wrong according to the Centre for Independent Studies.
Mr Watt interjected.

Mr NICHOLLS: He was wrong according to CommSec. He was wrong according to Access Economics, and he was wrong according to the National Australia Bank. I hear those on my left interject, because that is their response: they put their fingers in their ears and say, ‘Don’t worry about it. We’ll put it on the spindometer. We’ll make another big whack. We’ll put it on the spindometer to try and buy our way to success at the next election.’

That is exactly what is happening right now with the budget that we can expect to see later today. Quite frankly, nobody believes this government when it comes to its promises in budgets. And so today we will again sit in this House and wait for a plan from a government that has no plan to repay the debt. As we wait for a plan from the government to bring the budget back into surplus, there will be another attempt at hope over the bitter experience that we have established in the last four years under this government, under this Premier and under this Treasurer. It will again be another slick spin document put forward to try to sugar coat the pain so that the electorate is convinced to vote for it one more time and to soften the political blow that this government is afraid is coming, a blow that it is afraid is coming as it runs the state into an $85 billion debt.

Ever since this government reneged on its promise not to sell assets and ever since it reneged on its promise not to impose a fuel tax, it has been saying to the public, ‘We have a plan.’ But that plan has not delivered anything. In the budget last year the total debt was going to go to $84 billion and then it was going to come down to $80 billion. Once again we find it is going up to $85 billion--$595,000 an hour, each and every hour, each and every day of each and every week. Just two years after the assets were put on the chopping block, were flogged off--the silver was sold--the debt is going to be more than it was when the initial program was put there. No-one should believe this government when it talks about asset sales. It flogged the assets off to pay the wages--to pay the wages because it was so inept that it could not control its own expenses, and that was despite a massive increase in taxes and charges.

Who has heard about the plan to get the AAA credit rating back? Remember that Q2 objective: ‘We will keep the AAA credit rating’--another broken promise, another broken commitment! The government said, ‘We will sell the assets to get the AAA credit rating back.’ That was the whole reason for it. That was the whole reason for it if one goes to the budget documents. That is not even mentioned as we head towards that $85 billion worth of debt. Queenslanders will be paying that almost $600,000 each day, each and every day.

The Treasurer makes claims about the surplus. He has made three separate claims about the deficit in fact this year, and none of them have proven to be true so far, and I do not think anyone believes the latest events will prove them to be true. He talks about economic growth and he talks about predictions for economic growth. This government has a record of never hitting its economic growth targets. In 2007-08 it predicted five per cent and got 3.75 per cent. This government cannot be believed.

Hansard-Body.A: (Bulimba--ALP) (11.55 am): I rise to speak about the announcement by the Premier and the Minister for Education and Industrial Relations last week of the plans to transition year 7 to secondary school. This is the latest plank in a raft of education initiatives which have been rolled out by the Labor government over the last decade and it marks this government quite simply as a reformer, as a government of ideas and a government for the future. This government knows that our children are our future. If we invest in the early years of a child’s life that sets them up, and this is what governments need to be investing in. This latest announcement positions our children to take best advantage of all of the opportunities which are available to them and will be available to them over the coming years. It will see the year 7 students of 2015 as the first of their cohort to be part of secondary school.

XML.Hansard-Body: But this will not be happening on its own. This transition is going to be supported by a comprehensive package of initiatives which address not only all of the opportunities which will be available but any of the challenges which might otherwise be involved with an initiative of this magnitude. Following on from the introduction of the full-time prep year in 2007 and the raising of the school entry age by six months, the time is now right for year 7s to transition to high school. It means that those prep children when they reach year 7 will be six months older on average--half of them will turn 13 years in year 7--and they will also be in their eighth year of school. This is the time of a child’s life when they are becoming more independent and when they are looking for challenges, and these same children will be part of some of the most exciting curriculum changes which have ever been instituted through the new national curriculum. We need to make sure that our students are in the best position possible to take advantage of this.

I know that a number of parents and others have expressed concerns about whether children of this age were too young to go into a secondary school environment, and being a parent myself I can understand this. That is why I was very pleased to see the concept of a junior secondary school being included as part of the year 7 transition. This will begin straightaway for years 8 and 9, with the year 7s being added in 2015. The junior secondary concept will mean these students will be in a physically different location in secondary schools and will receive pastoral care and extra support as they merge into a new environment.

What they will also now be able to get, however, which they simply could not get in a primary school are the specialised facilities and teaching which will make sure they are in the best position possible to take advantage of the new Australian curriculum. High-performing states like New South Wales and Victoria have had year 7 in high school for years. We want to make sure our year 7s have the same learning opportunities as these students and others across the country, and this new initiative will achieve that.

The government will be putting money where its mouth is to ensure the success of the initiative, with a significant investment in the state and non-state sectors to build new classrooms and buy extra teaching resources, support teachers and develop programs. A total of $328.2 million over four years will be allocated to implement the Flying Start initiatives. We will also provide recurrent funding of $293.8 million over five years, including $81 million to the non-state sector for capital assistance grants. There is so much to this initiative--so much support and encouragement, so much effort going into making it right. I refer to things like the additional funding to support year 7 students to travel to local secondary schools; up to 500 scholarships for state primary school teachers to prepare them for teaching in junior secondary; extra professional development programs for junior secondary teachers; and support for teachers to introduce the new Australian curriculum for 2013.

I wish I had time to talk about all the elements of the package and I am certainly looking forward to making sure that the people of the Bulimba electorate are aware of them. I was very pleased to spend quite some time talking to local principals, teachers, parents, P&C and P&F committees last year when the consultation was being conducted on Flying Start--in fact, surveying the entire electorate for people’s views, and I know that everyone will be pleased to see any of the important issues they raised being factored in.

I will say that now, more than any other time, is the time for a child who is engaged or who will be engaged in the future in the education system in Queensland. With the learning or earning reforms that we have introduced, the introduction of full-time prep, our plans to make kindergarten available to all Queensland children, our support for parents and carers to help their children be ready for school and life, our work with teachers, principals and schools to support them as they deliver quality learning opportunities and now with this latest series of announcements, things are just getting better and better in education.

Hansard-Body.A: (Toowoomba North--ALP) (12.01 pm): The Warrego Highway has been described as the backbone of sustainable economic growth and social wellbeing in southern Queensland and is a major contributor to regional, state and national economies. However, over many years now the condition of the road has deteriorated as a result of increasing use owing to a growing population associated with the pre-existing agricultural and pastoral industries but, more significantly, the fast-expanding coal and energy industry. The emergence of the $40 billion coal seam gas industry in the Surat Basin places even greater pressure on a highway that, even now, is struggling to meet its current traffic demands. Immediate and considerable action has and needs to be undertaken.

XML.Hansard-Body: As a result, in May 2010 I convened a road summit of relevant mayors, the RACQ president Richard Pietsch and others with the Minister for Main Roads, Mr Wallace, and the then Minister for Transport, Ms Nolan, to consider the urgent priorities for the upgrade of the Warrego Highway between Morven and Helidon over the next four years. The estimated cost is $380 million to provide 55 kilometres of widened road on all narrow seals, 50 kilometres of strengthening work on rough and out-of-shape pavement, preservation works, intersection upgrades and safety treatments at high-crash locations, up to six kilometres of four-lane duplication between Toowoomba and Oakey and additional overtaking lanes from Oakey to Dalby to generally achieve 10-kilometre intervals. Other priorities over five to eight years and then nine to 12 years were also agreed.

The summit’s submissions call on the federal government to commit immediate funds under the National Land Transport Network to halt the current deterioration of the highway, upgrade the highway to a standard that supports future economic development across southern Queensland and the Surat Basin region and improve safety for industry and the travelling public. With gross regional product forecast to double by 2031 to approximately $9.3 billion, with the most increase occurring between 2014 and 2018, the Warrego Highway needs sufficient upgrading to support both its current and future needs.

Last year, Main Roads completed its submission, which was forwarded by the Hon. Craig Wallace to the federal infrastructure minister, the Hon. Anthony Albanese. As a result of a request to meet with him to verbally support the submission, on 19 April this year Minister Albanese was good enough to travel to Toowoomba at my invitation to meet at my office with representatives of our region’s businesses, the transport industry--including the Transport Workers Union--the Toowoomba mayor, representing the region’s mayors, the local federal MP and me. In order to reiterate the importance of this case, on 2 June this year I travelled to Canberra where Minister Albanese was good enough to hear again my submissions in support of the upgrade. A joint press release was issued at the end of the meeting whereby the minister committed to continue to work in close consultation with the Queensland government to determine future priorities.

I am pleased that currently the Commonwealth is spending $140 million over a number of years, which includes $54 million to upgrade the Blacksoil interchange, $40 million for improvements between Roma and Mitchell, $10 million to build additional overtaking lanes and $5 million for new and refurbished rest stops. Of course, these amounts are additional to the $82.5 million that is being spent on flood repairs on the Warrego Highway. However, more has to be done, which is why I continue to do my best in advocating for the highway. I know our state roads minister, Mr Wallace, is right behind this cause and I am confident that the state government will always do what it can. I call on the federal government to quickly address this issue and increase its commitment to the upgrade as well as, of course, addressing the ever-present need for an alternative method of road transport down the range at Toowoomba. The need for a second range crossing to get rid of the transports through Toowoomba is beyond argument.

Notwithstanding the Warrego Highway being a federal road and, hence, a federal responsibility, the state’s efforts have been commendable. At the community cabinet in Toowoomba in March 2011, $11 million of work to the Warrego Highway as constituted by James Street was announced to upgrade the intersection of Geddes, Neil and Hume streets and also the intersection of Tor and Bridge streets. This week, resurfacing work will be carried out on Tor Street between Hursley Road and Taylor Street. I was absolutely delighted to read in today’s Chronicle that the state will carry out four-laning work on the Warrego Highway on a significant stretch between Toowoomba and Oakey at a huge cost of $96 million. Thank you, Minister. This is state money being spent on a federal road. I call on the federal government to at least match this amount or put a similar amount towards construction of the second range crossing. The state government continues to show the way in the most important example of regional transport infrastructure improvement.

Hansard-Body.A: (Moggill--LNP) (12.05 pm): The wait is over after almost 500 days of indecision and dithering by a government that was unable to make a decision or work out how it was going to pay for the move of year 7. The government missed its own 2014 deadline and backflipped on its own Flying Start discussion paper that overlooked the fact that there is a recurrent cost in moving 50,000 students into high school in this state.

XML.Hansard-Body: The other side tries to attack the opposition by saying that we have no policies. That is a myth. Months ago I laid out this side’s policy in relation to year 7 and I am pleased that in some respects I seem to have helped the government a little bit because it has taken up some of the issues that I raised. Moving year 7 to high school in the environment of a national curriculum has merit in principle. We in the LNP have certainly not opposed this principle. But, as with so many other things with this government, the devil is in the detail. The detail in this move is that it is being done on the cheap.

The government, by sprouting $660-odd million over five years, conveniently ignores the fact that this money is predominantly coming out of existing education budgets. The government is taking money from other areas of education to fund the move that it was not prepared to fund adequately to make it work. Even the $80 million--meagre as that is in the scheme of this move for the non-government sector--is not new money. It is money that was already earmarked to go into capital works in the non-government sector. It has simply been shifted with only a bare minimum of new money.

This money is budgeted over five years. Our 50,000 students will be in high school in sooner than five years. It is smoke and mirrors--making money that is not there looking like it is. Like the Flying Start paper that ignored completely the issue of recurrent expenditure--the extra $100 million that it would cost just to have those students in high school--this latest release is just as deficient. With 50,000 new students in high schools, not one new high school is proposed in the government’s release.

I need look no further than Kenmore State High School, located in the western suburbs of Brisbane. That high school already has the most stringent enrolment management so that people who can walk to the school cannot even send their kids to the school. It is at 103 per cent capacity. In 2015, it is going to be expected to take another 400 students. If there is any chance of making this proposal work, this government is relying on forcing thousands more Queensland parents to pay private school fees. We are still sending thousands of students to high schools in Queensland who do not meet minimum standards of literacy and numeracy. We cannot even get the basics right.

The introduction of the prep year was a good idea, but it has not delivered on all of its benefits because we have sent teachers out without teacher aides. The government cannot even be honest about the age of children. If one goes to its website, it states that the children’s cohort that will enter year 7 in 2015 were born between 1 July 2002 and 30 June 2003. In fact, the oldest will be only 12 years old when they go to high school, the youngest only 11 years old. It cannot even be honest about the age of students entering high school.

I have real concerns about the resourcing to make this effective and avoid harming our education system. Rural and remote students who have been offered a few little trinkets by the government in fact will be up for greater boarding fees, lower bandings and smaller enrolments in their community primary schools.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Autism Spectrum Disorder, Cooperative Research Centre
XML.Hansard-Body:
Mr KILBURN (Chatsworth--ALP)
(12.10 pm): After meeting with a number of parents of children with ASD in my electorate, I took it upon myself to educate myself more about the difficulties faced by people with autism spectrum disorder, their parents and the people who care for and educate them. Earlier this year I visited the Autism Queensland headquarters at Sunnybank and was able to speak with the dedicated and committed people who have vast knowledge and experience in the field of autism spectrum disorder. After this initial visit I met with Dr Jill Ashburner, Manager, Research and Development, Autism Queensland, to learn more about a proposal for a cooperative research centre for living with autism spectrum disorder. This proposal for a CRC into autism was initiated by Autism Queensland and the University of Queensland. An information workshop was held in Brisbane in 2010 with 63 participants, including universities, hospitals and government organisations. At the end of the process there was full support for progressing the CRC application.

The CRC application has three main areas of research which have been developed using information provided during the consultation process. I have been told by parents of children with ASD as well as teachers that, due to the time it takes to obtain a verification for ASD, it is often difficult to ensure the students are receiving the proper support needed for them in prep and year 1. This can lead to significant delays in the learning process, so it is not surprising that the first area of research of the CRC is to improve the ability to correctly diagnose ASD through the identification of biomarkers with the potential to be used in diagnosis to develop a nationally endorsed protocol for accurate, efficient and faster evidence based diagnosis. They are also going to look at procedures and development programs to support the period around diagnosis and deliver a seamless integration between diagnosis and early intervention services.

The second part of the program is called Creating a Future and is focused on providing an enhanced education outcome for people with ASD. This is an important part of the development of people and prepares them for life as an adult. It will also provide options for better supporting our teachers by developing ASD-friendly curriculum and assessment approaches. The third area of research is around finding a place in society for adults with ASD. This is important so that we can develop tailored programs to support young people and adults with ASD by developing adult education programs, social interaction programs, emotional regulation and relation programs and developing effective programs to support vocational education and training and higher education.

I have seen and heard from parents, teachers and caregivers about the difficulties and stresses faced in caring for and educating children and adults with ASD. There is a great deal of goodwill amongst educators, carers and support groups. However, I acknowledge that there are issues that are complex and difficult. There are concerns from teachers that time spent dealing with one child with ASD is at times affecting their ability to deal with the other 26 or 27 children in the room. Parents are frustrated about what is best for their children: a fully inclusive program or a more focused and individual education process. I have had parents express to me that they would prefer more time being spent on developing social and living skills to ensure a better quality of life.

I fully support the application for the CRC by Autism Queensland and the University of Queensland. However, I believe it is also time for the Queensland government, through the parliamentary process, to get a parliamentary committee to investigate ways that we can improve the delivery of services for people affected by ASD through improved cooperation between government departments. I believe that we can do better and, for the sake of people with ASD and their parents, we must do better. I have seen the despair of some parents and I think it is best highlighted by the words of Kerry Norris, a parent of a child with ASD. She says--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: You my child are like a diamond in the rough. A sweet innocent little boy yet who possesses the ability to change so suddenly to an angry and confused soul with a demeanour all so tough. Therefore I am left wondering just what shall become of you when you become more manly. Though in the meantime I shall watch over you as much as possible. Just as I shall burn a flame in my heart for you always for you are but one of my sons, treasuring your very existence, I am no fool. I know that you are somewhat different so in your name I shall not throw down my guns. For it would only be unwise of me not to live on and cherish you, but however I do wish that we would hear your beautiful voice a little more. However, I cannot hold this against you, not when you are struggling internally. This much I know to be true. It is as though you are fighting in your very own self inflicted war. All this aside, it does seem as though you can’t be stopped, for you are always in a hurry, running and playing until your heart is content, playing in your very own land of make believe. Still, I can’t help but worry, for dare anyone try to stop you or interfere ... Where you then lash out with your feet and fists. Because you harbour so much angst inside it must at some point rear its ugly head. Somewhere, somehow you let us all know that it exists only to then take it out on yourself when you have been disciplined.
XML.Hansard-Body: I fully support Autism Queensland’s application for a CRC and I ask all other members to do the same.

Mr CRIPPS (Hinchinbrook--LNP)
(12.15 pm): Two weeks ago today many Queenslanders woke up with a knot in their stomach. The previous evening they had seen on the ABC’s Four Corners program graphic and disturbing footage of the processing of cattle in a number of Indonesian abattoirs. Like many Queenslanders I was shocked by the mistreatment of the cattle on the program. The LNP deplores cruelty to animals and we supported the decision at the time to suspend the supply of Australian cattle to the particular abattoirs using these inhumane practices.

Furthermore, the LNP considers ongoing advances in animal welfare outcomes as integral to its ongoing support for the live export of cattle to Indonesia. The LNP believes Australia is best placed to encourage humane practices in Indonesian abattoirs. The efforts of the Australian live cattle export industry have led to the introduction of stunning in some abattoirs. There is a long way to go to see the wider use of stunning in Indonesia, but there would not have been any progress had the Australian industry not been involved. No other country exporting live cattle spends money raised by levies on domestic producers to educate their customer in the humane treatment of animals. The only reason the Australian live export industry has any influence is that it is a preferred supplier due to the quality of the product. The LNP believes the live cattle export industry and the federal government need to continue to make the promotion and adoption of stunning a priority in Indonesian abattoirs.

A week after the Four Corners program was broadcast, the federal minister for agriculture, Senator Joe Ludwig, made a decision to suspend the export of live cattle to all Indonesian abattoirs regardless of practices they utilise. The live export of cattle is a major economic driver in North Queensland. The ban has serious ramifications on cattle producers, employees on properties, transport operators and businesses supplying and servicing the industry. Another week of uncertainty passed before Minister Ludwig yesterday addressed the issue of compensation. Minister Ludwig proposes to force the cattle industry to compensate itself by directing its industry body to use funds accumulated from voluntary levies collected for marketing and promotion and redistribute them to affected producers.

The full suspension of the live cattle export to Indonesia was an active decision of the Gillard government to close a major export market for North Queensland cattle producers. The Gillard government has created this crisis in the state’s beef industry. The current crisis demonstrates that Minister Ludwig did not fully understand the ramifications of his decision to fully suspend the live export of Australian cattle to Indonesia. The Gillard government should accept responsibility for its decision and compensate cattle producers for the loss of this market. The Gillard government must also announce and outline an immediate plan to re-establish a controlled trade with Indonesia that makes cattle identifiable and traceable from the property boundary in Australia to the abattoir in Indonesia. There are abattoirs in Indonesia that meet Australia’s expectations and there are producers in North Queensland capable of monitoring the movement of their cattle through the supply chain.

The extent of the Bligh government’s response has been to set up a task force, supposedly to identify alternative markets. It is very disappointing that the Bligh government has made plan B its priority. Rather than admit defeat, the Bligh government should stand up for North Queensland cattle producers and demand that the Gillard government re-open a controlled export trade to Indonesia. There are too many livelihoods at risk in this industry for this to be the best the Gillard and Bligh governments can offer. The live cattle export trade is a significant part of North Queensland’s economy. The impact of an ongoing export ban will be enormous. The livelihoods of everyone working in this industry are in jeopardy. Premier Bligh and the state minister for agriculture should be fighting for the livelihoods of these Queenslanders.

The LNP does not believe domestic producers supplying cattle for export should be penalised because some Indonesian abattoirs use unacceptable practices. The ban on exports from Australia means Indonesia will source cattle from another supplier less interested and committed to encouraging abattoirs to adopt more humane practices. Small regional communities in Indonesia have no refrigeration capacity. The only way local people have access to fresh meat is to purchase it on a daily basis from a local wet market. There are those claiming abattoirs in Australia can accept and process these cattle. This is not true. In the first instance, the cattle are the wrong breeds. Secondly, the domestic market for beef would be flooded, reducing returns to domestic suppliers and impacting on the markets of substitute products such as chicken, pork, lamb and fish. If people are genuinely interested in animal welfare, they need to understand the best chance of cattle being treated humanely in Indonesian abattoirs is for the Australian live cattle export industry to continue promoting the adoption of stunning and other practices.

Hansard-Body.A: (Southport--ALP) (12.20 pm): How often have we said that you never know what is around the corner? Quite often I have said it myself but not thought deeply about it. However, a recent event gave me an example of exactly what it means and how a completely unforeseen and unpredictable event can devastate our lives. On the Wednesday of the last parliamentary sitting in Brisbane, I received a message from my son-in-law, Clive, that my daughter Ali and grandson Zac had been involved in a serious motor vehicle accident. He asked me to meet them at the Royal Brisbane Hospital. Upon arrival, I saw Zac and was told that, apart from a few bruises and some skin off his leg, he was virtually uninjured. Unfortunately, the news about Ali was not as good.

XML.Hansard-Body: Ali’s left leg was badly injured and she spent over six hours in the operating theatre, where the medical staff tried to save her leg. Notwithstanding their effort and expertise, Ali’s leg had to be amputated. Three weeks followed in ICU and ward 7A North amputee ward, where, with the care of the medical and nursing staff, Ali slowly recovered. She is now at home, using a wheelchair and crutches and preparing for the months ahead when she will be fitted with a prosthetic limb and will have to learn to walk again. She faces many challenges in the months and years ahead. However, if anyone is equipped to meet those challenges Ali is. She is a happy, energetic, intelligent and positive person. Of course, normally getting a rap from your father is not much of a rap, but I know that those who know her would agree with that assessment.

The response to this tragic event has been overwhelming from people who are good friends and those who are virtually unknown to the family. We have received cards, letters, emails, chocolates and flowers. Ali was able to share the flowers with other patients in the ward, because they could not all fit in her room. The Mater Dei Catholic Primary School and Ashgrove Memorial Kindergarten mothers have volunteered to make Henry’s and Zac’s lunches. They and other friends are still making meals. People have offered to look after the boys, mow the lawn and set up a roster to take Ali to and from the hospital for physio.

On behalf of the family, Ali, Clive and the boys, and also Ali’s mother, Lin, I thank all those who have sent messages of support, including members from across this House, media people, some of whom have worked with Ali, constituents, and friends from here and overseas. I thank the many witnesses who assisted Ali and looked after Zac until the ambulance arrived, particularly the young mother who ran off with Zac so he could not see what had happened to his mother. I thank the two men who were on their way to the gym and who reversed the car and applied a tourniquet to Ali’s leg, without which she probably would have bled to death. I also thank those who cared so well for Ali, including the ambulance officers who attended the scene and took both Ali and Zac to the Royal Brisbane Hospital. I thank the investigating police officers. I thank the medical, surgical, nursing and general staff at the hospital. They were all brilliant, professional and understanding. Nothing was too much trouble for them.

However, this tragic accident raises and highlights an important issue, which is elderly people driving. The gentleman responsible for the accident, which could have had more serious consequences, was 88 years of age. Age itself is not an indicator of driving ability, but it is generally accepted that as we get older our reflexes and reaction times are slower. Ali bears no animosity to this gentleman but says to me, ‘Dad, he should not have been driving.’ Exactly what caused the accident I will leave to the investigating police officers, but Ali, with Zac in his stroller, was waiting for a lift in a shopping centre car park when an out-of-control car mowed them down and jammed Ali against another car. She was able to push Zac’s pram away so he avoided the main impact. Even as she begged the driver to reverse the car, he remained frozen until bystanders came and reversed the car.

In other jurisdictions, after the age of 75 it is necessary to obtain a doctor’s certificate and to undergo a driving test.
